Towards (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-Approximate Flow Sparsifiers

Alexandr Andoni
Microsoft Research Email: andoni@microsoft.com â€ƒâ€ƒ Anupam Gupta
CMU and MSR Work supported in part by NSF awards CCF-0964474 and CCF-1016799, US-Israel BSF grant #2010426, and by a grant from the CMU-Microsoft Center for Computational Thinking. Email: anupamg@cs.cmu.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Robert Krauthgamer
Weizmann Institute Work supported in part by the Israel Science Foundation grant #897/13, the US-Israel BSF grant #2010418, and by the Citi Foundation. Email: robert.krauthgamer@weizmann.ac.il
Abstract

A useful approach to â€œcompressâ€ a large network GğºGitalic_G is to represent it with a flow-sparsifier, i.e., a small network Hğ»Hitalic_H that supports the same flows as GğºGitalic_G, up to a factor qâ‰¥1ğ‘1q\geq 1italic_q â‰¥ 1 called the quality of sparsifier. Specifically, we assume the network GğºGitalic_G contains a set of kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, shared with the network Hğ»Hitalic_H, i.e., TâŠ†Vâ¢(G)âˆ©Vâ¢(H)ğ‘‡ğ‘‰ğºğ‘‰ğ»T\subseteq V(G)\cap V(H)italic_T âŠ† italic_V ( italic_G ) âˆ© italic_V ( italic_H ), and we want Hğ»Hitalic_H to preserve all multicommodity flows that can be routed between the terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. The challenge is to construct Hğ»Hitalic_H that is small.

These questions have received a lot of attention in recent years, leading to some known tradeoffs between the sparsifierâ€™s quality qğ‘qitalic_q and its size |Vâ¢(H)|ğ‘‰ğ»|V(H)|| italic_V ( italic_H ) |. Nevertheless, it remains an outstanding question whether every GğºGitalic_G admits a flow-sparsifier Hğ»Hitalic_H with quality q=1+Îµğ‘1ğœ€q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_Îµ, or even q=Oâ¢(1)ğ‘ğ‘‚1q=O(1)italic_q = italic_O ( 1 ), and size |Vâ¢(H)|â‰¤fâ¢(k,Îµ)ğ‘‰ğ»ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğœ€|V(H)|\leq f(k,\varepsilon)| italic_V ( italic_H ) | â‰¤ italic_f ( italic_k , italic_Îµ ) (in particular, independent of |Vâ¢(G)|ğ‘‰ğº|V(G)|| italic_V ( italic_G ) | and the edge capacities).

Making a first step in this direction, we present new constructions for several scenarios:

  • â€¢

    Our main result is that for quasi-bipartite networks GğºGitalic_G, one can construct a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-flow-sparsifier of size polyâ¡(k/Îµ)polyğ‘˜ğœ€\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_Îµ ). In contrast, exact (q=1ğ‘1q=1italic_q = 1) sparsifiers for this family of networks are known to require size 2Î©â¢(k)superscript2Î©ğ‘˜2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    For networks GğºGitalic_G of bounded treewidth wğ‘¤witalic_w, we construct a flow-sparsifier with quality q=Oâ¢(logâ¡w/logâ¡logâ¡w)ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘¤ğ‘¤q=O(\log w/\log\log w)italic_q = italic_O ( roman_log italic_w / roman_log roman_log italic_w ) and size Oâ¢(wâ‹…polyâ¡(k))ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘¤polyğ‘˜O(w\cdot\operatorname{poly}(k))italic_O ( italic_w â‹… roman_poly ( italic_k ) ).

  • â€¢

    For general networks GğºGitalic_G, we construct a sketch sâ¢kâ¢(G)ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğºsk(G)italic_s italic_k ( italic_G ), that stores all the feasible multicommodity flows up to factor q=1+Îµğ‘1ğœ€q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_Îµ, and its size (storage requirement) is fâ¢(k,Îµ)ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğœ€f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_Îµ ).

1 Introduction

A powerful tool to deal with big graphs is to â€œcompressâ€ them by reducing their size â€” not only does it reduce their storage requirement, but often it also reveals opportunities for more efficient graph algorithms. Notable examples in this context include the cut and spectral sparsifiers of [BK96, ST04], which have had a huge impact on graph algorithmics. These sparsifiers reduce the number of edges of the graph, while preserving prominent features such as cut values and Laplacian spectrum, up to approximation factor 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ. This immediately improves the runtime of graph algorithms that depend on the number of edges, at the expense of (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-approximate solutions. Such sparsifiers reduce only the number of edges, but it is natural to wonder whether more is to be gained by reducing the number of nodes as well. This vision â€” of â€œnode sparsificationâ€ â€” already appears, say, in [FM95].

One promising notion of node sparsification is that of flow or cut sparsifiers, introduced in [HKNR98, Moi09, LM10], where we have a network (a term we use to denote edge-capacitated graphs) GğºGitalic_G, and the goal is to construct a smaller network Hğ»Hitalic_H that supports the same flows as GğºGitalic_G, up to a factor qâ‰¥1ğ‘1q\geq 1italic_q â‰¥ 1 called the quality of sparsifier Hğ»Hitalic_H. Specifically, we assume the network GğºGitalic_G contains a set Tğ‘‡Titalic_T of kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals shared with the network Hğ»Hitalic_H, i.e., TâŠ†Vâ¢(G)âˆ©Vâ¢(H)ğ‘‡ğ‘‰ğºğ‘‰ğ»T\subseteq V(G)\cap V(H)italic_T âŠ† italic_V ( italic_G ) âˆ© italic_V ( italic_H ), and we want Hğ»Hitalic_H to preserve all multicommodity flows that can be routed between the terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. (A formal definition is given in SectionÂ 2.) A somewhat simpler variant is a cut sparsifier, which preserves the single-commodity flow from every set SâŠ‚Tğ‘†ğ‘‡S\subset Titalic_S âŠ‚ italic_T to its complement Tâˆ–Sğ‘‡ğ‘†T\setminus Sitalic_T âˆ– italic_S, i.e., a minimum-cut in GğºGitalic_G of the terminals bipartition T=Sâˆª(Tâˆ–S)ğ‘‡ğ‘†ğ‘‡ğ‘†T=S\cup(T\setminus S)italic_T = italic_S âˆª ( italic_T âˆ– italic_S ). Throughout, we consider undirected networks (although some of the results apply also for directed networks), and unless we say explicitly otherwise, flow and cut sparsifiers refer to their node versions, i.e., networks on few nodes that support (almost) the same flow.

The main question is: what tradeoff can one achieve between the quality of a sparsifier and its size? This question has received a lot of attention in recent years. In particular, if the sparsifier is only supported on Tğ‘‡Titalic_T (achieves minimal size), one can guarantee quality qâ‰¤Oâ¢(logâ¡klogâ¡logâ¡k)ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜q\leq O\big{(}\frac{\log k}{\log\log k}\big{)}italic_q â‰¤ italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) [Moi09, LM10, CLLM10, EGK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT10, MM10]. On the other hand, with this minimal size, the (worst-case) quality must be qâ‰¥Î©~â¢(logâ¡k)ğ‘~Î©ğ‘˜q\geq\tilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{\log k})italic_q â‰¥ over~ start_ARG roman_Î© end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) [LM10, CLLM10, MM10], and thus a significantly better quality cannot be achieved without increasing the size of the sparsifier. The only other result for flow sparsifiers, due to [Chu12], achieves a constant quality sparsifiers whose size depends on the capacities in the original graph. (Her results give flow sparsifiers of size COâ¢(logâ¡logâ¡C)superscriptğ¶ğ‘‚ğ¶C^{O(\log\log C)}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( roman_log roman_log italic_C ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; here Cğ¶Citalic_C is the total capacity of edges incident to terminals and hence may be Î©â¢(nâ¢k)Î©ğ‘›ğ‘˜\Omega(nk)roman_Î© ( italic_n italic_k ) even for unit-capacity graphs.) For the simpler notion of cut sparsifiers, there are known constructions at the other end of the tradeoff. Specifically, one can achieve exact (quality q=1ğ‘1q=1italic_q = 1) cut sparsifier of size 22ksuperscript2superscript2ğ‘˜2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [HKNR98, KRTV12], however, the size must still be at least 2Î©â¢(k)superscript2Î©ğ‘˜2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [KRTV12, KR13] (for both cut and flow sparsifiers).

Taking cue from edge-sparsification results, and the above lower bounds, it is natural to focus on small sparsifiers that achieve quality 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ, for small Îµâ‰¥0ğœ€0\varepsilon\geq 0italic_Îµ â‰¥ 0. Note that for flow sparsifiers, we do not know of any bound on the size of the sparsifier that would depend only on kğ‘˜kitalic_k (and 1/Îµ1ğœ€1/\varepsilon1 / italic_Îµ), but not on nğ‘›nitalic_n or edge capacities. In fact, we do not even know whether it is possible to represent the sparsifier information theoretically (i.e., by a small-size sketch), let alone by a graph.

1.1 Results

Making a first step towards constructing high-quality sparsifiers of small size, we present constructions for several scenarios:

  • â€¢

    Our main result is for quasi-bipartite graphs, i.e., graphs where the non-terminals form an independent set (seeÂ [RV99]), and we construct for such networks a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-flow-sparsifier of size polyâ¡(k/Îµ)polyğ‘˜ğœ€\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_Îµ ). In contrast, exact (q=1ğ‘1q=1italic_q = 1) sparsifiers for this family of networks are known to require size 2Î©â¢(k)superscript2Î©ğ‘˜2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [KRTV12, KR13]. (See Theorem 6.2.)

  • â€¢

    For general networks GğºGitalic_G, we construct a sketch sâ¢kâ¢(G)ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğºsk(G)italic_s italic_k ( italic_G ), that stores all the feasible multicommodity flows up to factor q=1+Îµğ‘1ğœ€q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_Îµ, and has size (storage requirement) of fâ¢(k,Îµ)ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğœ€f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_Îµ ) words. This implies an affirmative answer to the above information-theoretic question on existence of flow sparsifiers, and raises the hope for a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-flow-sparsifier of size fâ¢(k,Îµ)ğ‘“ğ‘˜ğœ€f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_Îµ ). (See Theorem 3.2.)

  • â€¢

    For networks GğºGitalic_G of bounded treewidth wğ‘¤witalic_w, we construct a flow-sparsifier with quality q=Oâ¢(logâ¡wlogâ¡logâ¡w)ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘¤ğ‘¤q=O(\frac{\log w}{\log\log w})italic_q = italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_w end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_w end_ARG ) and size Oâ¢(wâ‹…polyâ¡(k))ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘¤polyğ‘˜O(w\cdot\operatorname{poly}(k))italic_O ( italic_w â‹… roman_poly ( italic_k ) ). (See Theorem 7.7.)

  • â€¢

    Series-parallel networks admit an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with Oâ¢(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ) vertices. (See Theorem 7.5.)

1.2 Techniques

Perhaps our most important contribution is the introduction of the three techniques listed below, and indeed, one can view our results from the prism of these three rather different approaches. In particular, applying these three techniques to quasi-bipartite graphs yields (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-quality sparsifiers whose sizes are (respectively) doubly-exponential, exponential, and polynomial in k/Îµğ‘˜ğœ€k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_Îµ.

  1. 1.

    Clumping: We first â€œdiscretizeâ€ the set of (almost) all possible multi-commodity demands into a finite set, whose size depends only on k/Îµğ‘˜ğœ€k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_Îµ, and then partition the graph vertices into a small number of â€œclustersâ€, so that clumping each cluster into a single vertex still preserves one (and eventually all) of the discretized demands. The idea of clumping vertices was used in the past to obtain exact (quality 1111) cut sparsifiers [HKNR98]. Flow-sparsifiers require, in effect, to preserve all metrics between the terminals rather than merely all inter-terminal cut metrics, and requires new ideas.

  2. 2.

    Splicing/Composition: Our Splicing Lemma shows that it is enough for the sparsifier to maintain flows routed using paths that do not contain internally any terminals. Our Composition Lemma shows that for a network obtained by gluing two networks along some subset of their terminals, gluing the respective sparsifiers (in the same manner) gives us a sparsifier for the glued network. These lemmas enable us to do â€œsurgeryâ€ on networks, to decompose and recompose them, so that we find good sparsifiers on smaller networks and then combine them together without loss of quality.

  3. 3.

    Sampling: This technique samples parts of the graph, while preserving the flows approximately. The main difficulty is to determine correct sampling probabilities (and correlations). This is the technical heart of the paper, and we outline its main ideas in SectionÂ 1.3.

We hope they will inspire ulterior constructions of high-quality flow sparsifiers for general graphs. The clumping techniques give information-theoretic bounds on flow-sparsification, and the splicing/composition approach proves useful for sparsification of bounded treewidth and series-parallel graphs (beyond what can be derived using their flow/cut gaps from known cut sparsifiers).

1.3 Outline of Our Sampling Approach

A classic approach to obtain an edge-sparsifier [Kar94, BK96, SS11] is to sample the edges of the graph and rescale appropriately. Here, we outline instead how to sample the vertices of the graph to obtain a small flow-sparsifier. We outline our main idea on quasi-bipartite graphs (where the non-terminals form an independent set), considering for simplicity the (simpler) question of cut sparsifiers, where we want to construct a smaller graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that preserves the minimum cut between every bipartition of terminals T=Sâˆª(Tâˆ–S)ğ‘‡ğ‘†ğ‘‡ğ‘†T=S\cup(T\setminus S)italic_T = italic_S âˆª ( italic_T âˆ– italic_S ). The main idea is to sample a small number of non-terminals vğ‘£vitalic_v, keeping only their incident edges, and rescaling the corresponding capacities. For a fixed bipartition T=SâˆªSÂ¯ğ‘‡ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†T=S\cup\bar{S}italic_T = italic_S âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, we can write the value of the min-cut as

Î±S,SÂ¯=âˆ‘vâˆ‰Tminâ¡{âˆ‘sâˆˆScsâ¢v,âˆ‘tâˆˆSÂ¯cvâ¢t}.subscriptğ›¼ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}=\sum_{v\notin T}\min\Big{\{}\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\Big{\}}.italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ‰ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } . (1.1)

(Here cxâ¢ysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦c_{xy}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the capacity of the edge xâ¢yğ‘¥ğ‘¦xyitalic_x italic_y.) Suppose we assign each non-terminal vğ‘£vitalic_v with some sampling probability pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then sample the non-terminals using these probabilities, letting Ivsubscriptğ¼ğ‘£I_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an indicator variable for whether vğ‘£vitalic_v was sampled. Then, for sampled vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s we re-normalize the capacities on incident edges by 1/pv1subscriptğ‘ğ‘£1/p_{v}1 / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., the new capacities are cv,tâ€²=cv,t/pvsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘£c^{\prime}_{v,t}=c_{v,t}/p_{v}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all tâˆˆTğ‘¡ğ‘‡t\in Titalic_t âˆˆ italic_T (non-sampled vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s are dropped). The new value of the min-cut in the sparsifier Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

Î±S,SÂ¯â€²=âˆ‘vâˆ‰TIv/pvâ‹…minâ¡{âˆ‘sâˆˆScsâ¢v,âˆ‘tâˆˆSÂ¯cvâ¢t}.subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼â€²ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘£ğ‘‡â‹…subscriptğ¼ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}}=\sum_{v\notin T}I_{v}/p_{v}\cdot\min\Big{\{}\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\Big{\}}.italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ‰ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… roman_min { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } . (1.2)

This classical estimator is unbiased, and hence each min-cut Î±S,SÂ¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is preserved in expectation.

The main challenge now is to prove that the above random sum concentrates around its expectation for â€œsmallâ€ values of pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, consider setting all pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal, say to polyâ¡(k)/|V|polyğ‘˜ğ‘‰\operatorname{poly}(k)/|V|roman_poly ( italic_k ) / | italic_V |. Even if all cs,vâˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£01c_{s,v}\in\{0,1\}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } (i.e., all edges in Eğ¸Eitalic_E have unit capacity), due to the min operation, it is possible that only very few terms in the summation in Eqn.Â (1.1) have nonzero contribution to Î±S,SÂ¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and are extremely unlikely to be sampled.

Our general approach is to employ importance sampling, where each pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is related to vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s contribution to the sum, namely minâ¡{âˆ‘sâˆˆScsâ¢v,âˆ‘tâˆˆSÂ¯cvâ¢t}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡\min\left\{\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\right\}roman_min { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Applying this directly is hard â€” since that minimum depends on the bipartition SâˆªSÂ¯ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†S\cup\bar{S}italic_S âˆª overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, whereas pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot. Instead, we exploit the fact that for any bipartition, we can estimate

Î±S,SÂ¯â€²â‰¥maxsâˆˆS,tâˆˆSÂ¯â¢âˆ‘vIv/pvâ‹…minâ¡{csâ¢v,cvâ¢t}â‰¥1k2â¢Î±S,SÂ¯â€²,subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼â€²ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘†ğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘†subscriptğ‘£â‹…subscriptğ¼ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘˜2subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼â€²ğ‘†Â¯ğ‘†\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}}\geq\max_{s\in S,t\in\bar{S}}\ \sum_{v}I_{v}/p_{v}\cdot\min\{c_{sv},c_{vt}\}\geq\tfrac{1}{k^{2}}\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}},italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ italic_S , italic_t âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1.3)

and hence arguing about the sum in Eqn.Â (1.3) should be enough for bounding the variance. Following this reasoning through, it turns out that a good choice is

pv=Mâ‹…maxsâ‰ tâ¡minâ¡{csâ¢v,cvâ¢t}âˆ‘vâ€²minâ¡{csâ¢vâ€²,cvâ€²â¢t},subscriptğ‘ğ‘£â‹…ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘¡p_{v}=M\cdot\max_{s\neq t}\frac{\min\{c_{sv},c_{vt}\}}{\sum_{v^{\prime}}\min\{c_{sv^{\prime}},c_{v^{\prime}t}\}},italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_M â‹… roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s â‰  italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG , (1.4)

where M=polyâ¡(k/Îµ)ğ‘€polyğ‘˜ğœ€M=\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)italic_M = roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_Îµ ) is an over-sampling factor. The underlying intuition of Eqn.Â (1.4) is that, replacing the max with a â€œcorrectâ€ choice of sâˆˆS,tâˆˆSÂ¯formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘†ğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘†s\in S,t\in\bar{S}italic_s âˆˆ italic_S , italic_t âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, the denominator is just the entire potential contribution to the sum in Eqn.Â (1.3), and hence these pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values can be used as importance sampling probabilities for the sum in Eqn.Â (1.2). Moreover, we prove that this setting of pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allows for a high-probability concentration bound in the sum from Eqn.Â (1.2), and thus sampling polyâ¡(k/Îµ)polyğ‘˜ğœ€\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_Îµ ) vertices suffices for the purpose of taking a union bound over all 2ksuperscript2ğ‘˜2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bipartitions.

So far we have described the approach for obtaining cut sparsifiers, but in fact we prove that the exact same approach works for obtaining flow sparsifiers as well. There are more issues that we need to take care in this generalized setting. First, we need to bound the â€œeffectiveâ€ number of demand vectors. Second, the flow does not have a simple closed-form formula like (1.1), so upper and lower bounds need to be proved by analyzing separately (the concentration of) the optimal value of the flow LP and of its dual.

2 Preliminaries

A kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network is an edge-capacitated graph G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) with a subset TâŠ†Vğ‘‡ğ‘‰T\subseteq Vitalic_T âŠ† italic_V of kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals. We will be interested only in terminal flows, i.e., flows that start and end only at the terminal vertices of GğºGitalic_G. Define ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), the demand polytope of GğºGitalic_G as the set of all demand vectors ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that are supported only on terminal-pairs, and admit a feasible multicommodity-flow in GğºGitalic_G, formally,

ğ’Ÿâ¢(G):={ğâˆˆâ„+(T2):demandÂ ğÂ can be routed inÂ G},assignğ’Ÿğºconditional-setğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2demandÂ ğÂ can be routed inÂ G\displaystyle{\mathcal{D}}(G):=\{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}:\ \text{demand $\mathbf{d}$ can be routed in $G$}\},caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) := { bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : demand bold_d can be routed in italic_G } , (2.5)

where we denote â„+:={xâˆˆR:xâ‰¥0}assignsubscriptâ„conditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘…ğ‘¥0{\mathbb{R}}_{+}:=\{x\in R:x\geq 0\}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { italic_x âˆˆ italic_R : italic_x â‰¥ 0 } and (T2):={SâŠ†T:|S|=2}assignbinomialğ‘‡2conditional-setğ‘†ğ‘‡ğ‘†2\tbinom{T}{2}:=\{S\subseteq T:\ \lvert S\rvert=2\}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) := { italic_S âŠ† italic_T : | italic_S | = 2 }. Throughout, we assume GğºGitalic_G is connected.

Lemma 2.1.

ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) is a polytope, and is down-monotone.

Proof.

Let ğ’«iâ¢jsubscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{P}_{ij}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of paths between terminals iğ‘–iitalic_i and jğ‘—jitalic_j. Consider the extended demand polytope ğ’Ÿeâ¢xâ¢tâ¢(G)subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğº{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) with variables diâ¢jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{ij}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all {i,j}âˆˆ(T2)ğ‘–ğ‘—binomialğ‘‡2\{i,j\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_i , italic_j } âˆˆ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), and fPsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ƒf_{P}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each Pâˆˆâˆªi,jğ’«iâ¢jğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘—P\in\cup_{i,j}\mathcal{P}_{ij}italic_P âˆˆ âˆª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

âˆ‘Pâˆˆğ’«iâ¢jfPsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{P\in\mathcal{P}_{ij}}f_{P}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =diâ¢jabsentsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle=d_{ij}= italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âˆ‘i,jâˆ‘Pâˆˆğ’«iâ¢j:eâˆˆPfPsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscript:ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’«ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘’ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{i,j}\sum_{P\in\mathcal{P}_{ij}:e\in P}f_{P}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P âˆˆ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_e âˆˆ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ceabsentsubscriptğ‘ğ‘’\displaystyle\leq c_{e}â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
fP,diâ¢jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle f_{P},d_{ij}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥0.absent0\displaystyle\geq 0.â‰¥ 0 .

This polytope captures all the feasible terminal flows, and hence all the routable demands between the terminals of GğºGitalic_G. The projection of this polytope ğ’Ÿeâ¢xâ¢tâ¢(G)subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğº{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) onto the variables dğ‘‘ditalic_d is exactly ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ); hence the latter is also a polytope.111As a aside, we can write ğ’Ÿeâ¢xâ¢tâ¢(G)subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğº{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) more compactly using edge-flow variables fiâ¢jâ¢(e)superscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘’f^{ij}(e)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) instead of path variables fPsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ƒf_{P}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; we omit such standard optimizations here. Finally, the down-monotonicity of the polytope follows from the downward-feasibility of flows, in turn due to the lack of lower-bounds on the flows on edges. âˆ

Dual linear program for concurrent flow.

For a demand vector ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 }, we denote the concurrent flow problem (inverse of the congestion) by

Î»Gâ¢(ğ):=sup{Î»â‰¥0:Î»â¢ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G)}.assignsubscriptğœ†ğºğsupremumconditional-setğœ†0ğœ†ğğ’Ÿğº\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}):=\sup\{\lambda\geq 0:\ \lambda\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)\}.italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) := roman_sup { italic_Î» â‰¥ 0 : italic_Î» bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) } .

This is well-defined because 0â†’âˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G)â†’0ğ’Ÿğº\vec{0}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)overâ†’ start_ARG 0 end_ARG âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). Lemma 2.2.

Flow-sparsifier definition.

A network Gâ€²=(Vâ€²,Eâ€²,câ€²)superscriptğºâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²superscriptğ¸â€²superscriptğ‘â€²G^{\prime}=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with TâŠ†Vâ€²ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‰â€²T\subseteq V^{\prime}italic_T âŠ† italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a flow sparsifier of GğºGitalic_G with quality qâ‰¥1ğ‘1q\geq 1italic_q â‰¥ 1 if

âˆ€dâˆˆâ„+(T2),Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)â‰¤qâ‹…Î»Gâ¢(ğ).formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2subscriptğœ†ğºğsubscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğâ‹…ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğºğ\forall d\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}},\qquad\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\leq q\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}).âˆ€ italic_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_q â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) .

This condition is equivalent to writing ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)âŠ†ğ’Ÿâ¢(Gâ€²)âŠ†qâ‹…ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğºğ’Ÿsuperscriptğºâ€²â‹…ğ‘ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)\subseteq{\mathcal{D}}(G^{\prime})\subseteq q\cdot{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) âŠ† caligraphic_D ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âŠ† italic_q â‹… caligraphic_D ( italic_G ).

3 A Data Structure for Multicommodity Flows

We present a data structure that â€œmaintainsâ€ ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) within approximation factor 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ. More precisely, we preprocess the terminal network GğºGitalic_G into a data structure whose storage requirement depends only on kğ‘˜kitalic_k and Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ (but not on n=|Vâ¢(G)|ğ‘›ğ‘‰ğºn=|V(G)|italic_n = | italic_V ( italic_G ) |). Given a query ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, this data structure returns an approximation to Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) within factor 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ (without further access to GğºGitalic_G). The formal statement appears in Theorem 3.2. We assume henceforth that 0<Îµ<180ğœ€180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_Îµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG.

An approximate polytope.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a terminal network with k terminals TâŠ‚Vğ‘‡ğ‘‰T\subset Vitalic_T âŠ‚ italic_V. For each commodity {i,j}âˆˆ(T2)ğ‘–ğ‘—binomialğ‘‡2\{i,j\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_i , italic_j } âˆˆ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), let Liâ¢jsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the maximum flow of commodity iâ¢jğ‘–ğ‘—ijitalic_i italic_j alone (i.e., as a single-commodity flow) in GğºGitalic_G. Discretize the set ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) defined inÂ (2.5) by defining the subset

ğ’ŸÎµdiscrete:={ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G):every nonzeroÂ diâ¢jÂ is a power ofÂ 1+ÎµÂ in the rangeÂ [Îµ/k2â‹…Liâ¢j,Liâ¢j]Â }.assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discreteconditional-setğğ’Ÿğºevery nonzeroÂ diâ¢jÂ is a power ofÂ 1+ÎµÂ in the rangeÂ [Îµ/k2â‹…Liâ¢j,Liâ¢j]Â {\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}:=\{\,\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G):\ \text{every nonzero $d_{ij}$ is a power of $1+\varepsilon$ in the range $[\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij},L_{ij}]$\, }\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) : every nonzero italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a power of 1 + italic_Îµ in the range [ italic_Îµ / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] } .

The range upper bound Liâ¢jsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which is not really necessary, as it follows from ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğğ’Ÿğº\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G )), immediately implies that

|ğ’ŸÎµdiscrete|â‰¤(1+1Îµâ¢log1+Îµâ¡k)(k2)â‰¤(Oâ¢(1)Îµâ¢logâ¡k)k2.superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discretesuperscript11ğœ€subscript1ğœ€ğ‘˜binomialğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘‚1ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert\leq\Big{(}1+\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log_{1+\varepsilon}k\Big{)}^{\binom{k}{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{O(1)}{\varepsilon}\log k\Big{)}^{k^{2}}.| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( divide start_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3.6)
Lemma 3.1.

The convex hull convâ¡(ğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’)normal-convsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is down-monotone, namely, if ğâˆˆconvâ¡(ğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’)ğnormal-convsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’\mathbf{d}\in\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})bold_d âˆˆ roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and 0â‰¤ğ^â‰¤ğ0normal-^ğğ0\leq\widehat{\mathbf{d}}\leq\mathbf{d}0 â‰¤ over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG â‰¤ bold_d, then also ğ^âˆˆconvâ¡(ğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’)normal-^ğnormal-convsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’\widehat{\mathbf{d}}\in\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG âˆˆ roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof.

Consider first the special case where ğ^^ğ\widehat{\mathbf{d}}over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG is obtained from ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d by scaling the coordinates in some subset SâŠ†(T2)ğ‘†binomialğ‘‡2S\subseteq\binom{T}{2}italic_S âŠ† ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) by a scalar 0â‰¤Î²<10ğ›½10\leq\beta<10 â‰¤ italic_Î² < 1. Write ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d as a convex combination of some vectors ğjâˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscretesubscriptğğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}_{j}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, say âˆ‘jÎ±jâ¢ğjsubscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—subscriptğğ‘—\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}\mathbf{d}_{j}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î±j>0subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—0\alpha_{j}>0italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 and âˆ‘jÎ±j=1subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—1\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Let ğ^jsubscript^ğğ‘—\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j}over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector obtained from ğjsubscriptğğ‘—\mathbf{d}_{j}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by zeroing all the coordinates in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, and observe it is also in ğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now write

ğ^=âˆ‘jÎ±jâ¢[Î²â¢ğj+(1âˆ’Î²)â¢ğ^j]=âˆ‘jÎ±jâ¢Î²â¢ğj+âˆ‘jÎ±jâ¢(1âˆ’Î²)â¢ğ^j,^ğsubscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ›½subscriptğğ‘—1ğ›½subscript^ğğ‘—subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—ğ›½subscriptğğ‘—subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—1ğ›½subscript^ğğ‘—\widehat{\mathbf{d}}=\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}[\beta\mathbf{d}_{j}+(1-\beta)\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j}]=\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}\beta\mathbf{d}_{j}+\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}(1-\beta)\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j},over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Î² bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Î² ) over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Î² ) over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and observe the right-hand side is a convex combination of vectors in ğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which proves the aforementioned special case. The general case follows by iterating this special-case argument several times. âˆ

The data structure.

The next theorem expresses the space requirement of an algorithm in machine words, assuming every machine word can store logâ¡kğ‘˜\log kroman_log italic_k bits and any single value Liâ¢jsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (either exactly or within accuracy factor 1+Îµ/21ğœ€21+\varepsilon/21 + italic_Îµ / 2). This holds, in particular, when edge capacities in the graph GğºGitalic_G are integers bounded by n=|Vâ¢(G)|ğ‘›ğ‘‰ğºn=\lvert V(G)\rvertitalic_n = | italic_V ( italic_G ) |, and a word has 2â¢logâ¡n2ğ‘›2\log n2 roman_log italic_n bits.

Theorem 3.2.

For every 0<Îµ<180ğœ€180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_Îµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG there is a data structure that provides a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ )-approximation for multicommodity flows in a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, using space (Oâ¢(1)Îµâ¢logâ¡k)k2superscriptğ‘‚1ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2\Big{(}\tfrac{O(1)}{\varepsilon}\log k\Big{)}^{k^{2}}( divide start_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and query time Oâ¢(1Îµâ¢k2â¢logâ¡k)ğ‘‚1ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘˜O(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}k^{2}\log k)italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ).

Proof.

We present a data structure achieving approximation 1+Oâ¢(Îµ)1ğ‘‚ğœ€1+O(\varepsilon)1 + italic_O ( italic_Îµ ); the theorem would then follow by scaling Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 appropriately. The data structure stores the set ğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, using a dictionary (such as a hash table) to answer membership queries in time Oâ¢(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), the time required to read a single vector. It additionally stores all the values Liâ¢jsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (We assume these values can be stored exactly; the case of 1+Îµ/21ğœ€21+\varepsilon/21 + italic_Îµ / 2 approximation follows by straightforward modifications.)

Given a query ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, the algorithm first computes Î²=mini,jâˆˆTâ¡{Liâ¢j/diâ¢j}ğ›½subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\beta=\min_{i,j\in T}\{L_{ij}/d_{ij}\}italic_Î² = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j âˆˆ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. We thus have that Î²â¢kâˆ’2â‰¤Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î²ğ›½superscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğœ†ğºğğ›½\beta k^{-2}\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\betaitalic_Î² italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_Î², because the commodity i,jâˆˆTğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j âˆˆ italic_T attaining Î²â¢diâ¢j=Liâ¢jğ›½subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\beta d_{ij}=L_{ij}italic_Î² italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT limits Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) to not exceed Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², and because we can ship Î²â¢diâ¢jâ‰¤Liâ¢jğ›½subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\beta d_{ij}\leq L_{ij}italic_Î² italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT units separately for every commodity i,jâˆˆTğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j âˆˆ italic_T, hence also their convex combination (k2)âˆ’1â¢Î²â¢ğsuperscriptbinomialğ‘˜21ğ›½ğ\binom{k}{2}^{-1}\beta\mathbf{d}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² bold_d.

The query algorithm then computes an estimate for Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) by performing a binary search over all powers of (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ) in the range [Î²â¢kâˆ’2,Î²]ğ›½superscriptğ‘˜2ğ›½[\beta k^{-2},\beta][ italic_Î² italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î² ], where each iteration decides, up to 1+2â¢Îµ12ğœ€1+2\varepsilon1 + 2 italic_Îµ multiplicative approximation, whether a given Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» in that range is at most Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). The number of iterations is clearly Oâ¢(log1+Îµâ¡k2)â‰¤Oâ¢(1Îµâ¢logâ¡k)ğ‘‚subscript1ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘‚1ğœ€ğ‘˜O(\log_{1+\varepsilon}k^{2})\leq O(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ).

The approximate decision procedure is performed in two steps. In the first step, we let ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from Î»â¢ğğœ†ğ\lambda\mathbf{d}italic_Î» bold_d by zeroing all coordinates that are at most 2â¢Îµ/k2â‹…Liâ¢jâ‹…2ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—2\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij}2 italic_Îµ / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This vector can be written as

ğâˆ’=Î»â¢ğâˆ’âˆ‘i,jâˆˆTÎ±iâ¢jâ¢Liâ¢jâ¢ğiâ¢j,superscriptğğœ†ğsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{d}^{-}=\lambda\mathbf{d}-\sum_{i,j\in T}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij},bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î» bold_d - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j âˆˆ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where ğiâ¢jâˆˆâ„+(T2)subscriptğğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2\mathbf{e}_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the standard basis vector corresponding to {i,j}ğ‘–ğ‘—\{i,j\}{ italic_i , italic_j }, and for every i,jâˆˆTğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j âˆˆ italic_T we define Î±iâ¢j:=diâ¢j/Liâ¢jassignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij}:=d_{ij}/L_{ij}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if diâ¢jâ‰¤2â¢Îµ/k2â‹…Liâ¢jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…2ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{ij}\leq 2\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 2 italic_Îµ / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Î±iâ¢j:=0assignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—0\alpha_{ij}:=0italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0 otherwise. By definition, âˆ‘i,jÎ±i,jâ‰¤Îµsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€\sum_{i,j}\alpha_{i,j}\leq\varepsilonâˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Îµ. The second step lets ğâ€²superscriptğâ€²\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by rounding down each coordinate to the nearest power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ. Finally, decide whether Î»â‰¤Î»Gâ¢(ğ)ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) by checking whether ğâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptğâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is implemented using the dictionary in Oâ¢(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

It remains to prove the correctness of the approximate decision procedure. For one direction, assume that Î»â‰¤Î»Gâ¢(ğ)ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). It follows that the demands Î»â¢ğâ‰¥ğâˆ’â‰¥ğâ€²ğœ†ğsuperscriptğsuperscriptğâ€²\lambda\mathbf{d}\geq\mathbf{d}^{-}\geq\mathbf{d}^{\prime}italic_Î» bold_d â‰¥ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can all be routed in GğºGitalic_G, and furthermore ğâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptğâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, implying that our procedure reports a correct decision. For the other direction, suppose our procedure reports that Î»â‰¤Î»Gâ¢(ğ)ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which means that its corresponding ğâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscreteâŠ‚ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)superscriptğâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discreteğ’Ÿğº\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\subset{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ‚ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). We can thus write

Î»â¢ğ=ğâˆ’+âˆ‘iâ¢jÎ±iâ¢jâ¢Liâ¢jâ¢ğiâ¢jâ‰¤(1+Îµ)â¢ğâ€²+âˆ‘iâ¢jÎ±iâ¢jâ¢Liâ¢jâ¢ğiâ¢j.ğœ†ğsuperscriptğsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğğ‘–ğ‘—1ğœ€superscriptğâ€²subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij}\leq(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{\prime}+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij}.italic_Î» bold_d = bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The right-hand side can be described as a positive combination of vectors in ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), whose sum of coefficients is (1+Îµ)+âˆ‘iâ¢jÎ±iâ¢jâ‰¤1+2â¢Îµ1ğœ€subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—12ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}\leq 1+2\varepsilon( 1 + italic_Îµ ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 1 + 2 italic_Îµ. Since ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) is convex and contains 0Â¯Â¯0\underline{0}underÂ¯ start_ARG 0 end_ARG, we have that also (1+2â¢Îµ)âˆ’1â¢Î»â¢ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G)superscript12ğœ€1ğœ†ğğ’Ÿğº(1+2\varepsilon)^{-1}\lambda\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)( 1 + 2 italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), i.e., that (1+2â¢Îµ)âˆ’1â¢Î»â‰¤Î»Gâ¢(ğ)superscript12ğœ€1ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğºğ(1+2\varepsilon)^{-1}\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})( 1 + 2 italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which proves the correctness of the decision procedure up to 1+2â¢Îµ12ğœ€1+2\varepsilon1 + 2 italic_Îµ multiplicative approximation. Overall, we have indeed shown that the binary search algorithm approximates Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) within factor (1+Îµ)â¢(1+2â¢Îµ)â‰¤1+Oâ¢(Îµ)1ğœ€12ğœ€1ğ‘‚ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)(1+2\varepsilon)\leq 1+O(\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ) ( 1 + 2 italic_Îµ ) â‰¤ 1 + italic_O ( italic_Îµ ). âˆ

4 The Clumping Method for Flow Sparsifiers

In this section we develop a method based on clumping (merging) vertices, and exemplify its use on quasi-bipartite graphs. Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a terminal network with terminal set Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. For a subset SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq Vitalic_S âŠ† italic_V, denote the edges in the induced subgraph Gâ¢[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S]italic_G [ italic_S ] by Eâ¢[S]:={(u,v)âˆˆE:u,vâˆˆS}assignğ¸delimited-[]ğ‘†conditional-setğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ¸ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘†E[S]:=\{(u,v)\in E:\ u,v\in S\}italic_E [ italic_S ] := { ( italic_u , italic_v ) âˆˆ italic_E : italic_u , italic_v âˆˆ italic_S }. Given a partition Î ={S1,S2,â€¦,Sm}Î subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘š\Pi=\{S_{1},S_{2},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Î  = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of the vertex set (i.e., âˆªi=1mSi=Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘‰\cup_{i=1}^{m}S_{i}=Vâˆª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V), say a distance function Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ on the vertex set Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is Î normal-Î \Piroman_Î -respecting if for all lâˆˆ[m]ğ‘™delimited-[]ğ‘šl\in[m]italic_l âˆˆ [ italic_m ] and {i,j}âˆˆSlğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘†ğ‘™\{i,j\}\in S_{l}{ italic_i , italic_j } âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it holds that Î´iâ¢j=0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—0\delta_{ij}=0italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Proposition 4.1.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, and fix 0<Îµ<1/30ğœ€130<\varepsilon<1/30 < italic_Îµ < 1 / 3 and bâ‰¥1ğ‘1b\geq 1italic_b â‰¥ 1. Suppose there is an mğ‘šmitalic_m-way partition Î ={S1,â€¦,Sm}normal-Î subscriptğ‘†1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘š\Pi=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Î  = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } such that for every ğâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’superscriptğnormal-â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists a Î normal-Î \Piroman_Î -respecting distance function Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ that is a feasible solution toÂ (LP1) with objective value at most bâ‹…Î»Gâ¢(ğâ€²)normal-â‹…ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğºsuperscriptğnormal-â€²b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})italic_b â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then the graph Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained from GğºGitalic_G by merging each Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a single vertex (keeping parallel edges222From our perspective of flows, parallel edges can also be merged into one edge with the same total capacity. ) is a flow-sparsifier of GğºGitalic_G with quality (1+3â¢Îµ)â¢b13ğœ€ğ‘(1+3\varepsilon)b( 1 + 3 italic_Îµ ) italic_b.

Proof.

Formally, let Gâ€²=(V,EâˆªE0,câ€²)superscriptğºâ€²ğ‘‰ğ¸subscriptğ¸0superscriptğ‘â€²G^{\prime}=(V,E\cup E_{0},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V , italic_E âˆª italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) where câ€²â¢(e)=câ¢(e)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘’c^{\prime}(e)=c(e)italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) = italic_c ( italic_e ) if eâˆˆEğ‘’ğ¸e\in Eitalic_e âˆˆ italic_E and câ€²â¢(e)=âˆsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘’c^{\prime}(e)=\inftyitalic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) = âˆ if eâˆˆE0ğ‘’subscriptğ¸0e\in E_{0}italic_e âˆˆ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then for any ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it is immediate that Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)â‰¥Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğsubscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d )â€”every flow that is feasible in GğºGitalic_G is also feasible in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even without shipping any flow on E0subscriptğ¸0E_{0}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

By our premise, the demand ğâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscretesuperscriptğâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a Î Î \Piroman_Î -respecting feasible solution {Î´sâ¢t,â„“e}subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptâ„“ğ‘’\{\delta_{st},\ell_{e}\}{ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with value at most bâ‹…Î»Gâ¢(ğâ€²)â‹…ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğºsuperscriptğâ€²b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})italic_b â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ); note that such a Î Î \Piroman_Î -respecting distance function is also a solution toÂ (LP2). The next proposition is similar in spirit to the previous one, but with the crucial difference that it allows (or assumes) a different partition of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V for every demand ğâˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscreteğsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its proof is a simple application of the PropositionÂ 4.1.

Proposition 4.2.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, and fix 0<Îµ<1/30ğœ€130<\varepsilon<1/30 < italic_Îµ < 1 / 3, bâ‰¥1ğ‘1b\geq 1italic_b â‰¥ 1, and mâ‰¥1ğ‘š1m\geq 1italic_m â‰¥ 1. Suppose that for every ğâˆˆğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there is an mğ‘šmitalic_m-way partition Î ğ={S1,â€¦,Sm}subscriptnormal-Î ğsubscriptğ‘†1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘š\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (with some sets Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT potentially empty) and a Î ğsubscriptnormal-Î ğ\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-respecting distance function that is a feasible solution toÂ (LP1) with objective value at most bâ‹…Î»Gâ¢(ğ)normal-â‹…ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğºğb\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_b â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). Then GğºGitalic_G has a flow-sparsifier Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality (1+3â¢Îµ)â¢b13ğœ€ğ‘(1+3\varepsilon)b( 1 + 3 italic_Îµ ) italic_b, which has

|Vâ¢(Gâ€²)|â‰¤m|ğ’ŸÎµğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’|â‰¤m(Îµâˆ’1â¢logâ¡k)k2ğ‘‰superscriptğºâ€²superscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’superscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsuperscriptğœ€1ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2\lvert V(G^{\prime})\rvert\leq m^{\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert}\leq m^{(\varepsilon^{-1}\log k)^{k^{2}}}| italic_V ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | â‰¤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

vertices. Moreover, this graph Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by merging vertices in GğºGitalic_G.

Proof.

For every demand ğâˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscreteğsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we know there is an appropriate mğ‘šmitalic_m-way partition Î ğsubscriptÎ ğ\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Imposing all these partitions simultaneously yields a â€œrefinedâ€ partition Î ={S1â€²,â€¦,Smâ€²â€²}Î subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²\Pi=\{S^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{m^{\prime}}\}roman_Î  = { italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in which the number of parts is mâ€²â‰¤m|ğ’ŸÎµdiscrete|superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discretem^{\prime}\leq m^{\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and two vertices in the same part Sjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—S^{\prime}_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of this refined partition if and only if they are in the same part of every initial partition. Now apply PropositionÂ 4.1 using this mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-way partition (using that any Î ğsubscriptÎ ğ\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-respecting distance function is also a Î Î \Piroman_Î -respecting one), we obtain graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is a flow-sparsifier of GğºGitalic_G and has at most mâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vertices. Finally, we bound |ğ’ŸÎµdiscrete|superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discrete\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | using (3.6). âˆ

4.1 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs via Clumping

As a warm-up, we use PropositionÂ 4.2 to construct a graph sparsifier for quasi-bipartite graphs with quality (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ), where the size of the sparsifier is only a function of kğ‘˜kitalic_k and Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ. Recall that a graph GğºGitalic_G with terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is quasi-bipartite if the non-terminals form an independent setÂ [RV99]. For this discussion, we assume that the terminals form an independent set as well, by subdividing every terminal-terminal edgeâ€”hence the graph is just bipartite.

Theorem 4.3.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, and let Îµâˆˆ(0,18)ğœ€018\varepsilon\in(0,{\tfrac{1}{8}})italic_Îµ âˆˆ ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ). Then GğºGitalic_G admits a quality 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ flow-sparsifier G^normal-^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG of size expâ¡{Oâ¢(kâ¢logâ¡kÎµâ¢(1Îµâ¢logâ¡k)k2)}ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğœ€superscript1ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2\exp\{O(k\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)^{k^{2}})\}roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }.

Proof.

To apply Proposition 4.2, the main challenge is to bound mğ‘šmitalic_m, the number of parts in the partition. To this end, fix a demand ğâˆˆğ’ŸÎµdiscreteâŠ†ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğœ€discreteğ’Ÿğº\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\subseteq{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), and let {â„“e,Î´iâ¢j}subscriptâ„“ğ‘’subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\{\ell_{e},\delta_{ij}\}{ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be an optimal solution for the linear program (LP1), hence its value is âˆ‘eâˆˆEceâ¢â„“e=Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğ‘’ğ¸subscriptğ‘ğ‘’subscriptâ„“ğ‘’subscriptğœ†ğºğ\sum_{e\in E}c_{e}\ell_{e}=\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). We will modify this solution into another one, {â„“eâ€²,Î´iâ¢jâ€²}subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—\{\ell^{\prime}_{e},\delta^{\prime}_{ij}\}{ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, that satisfies the desired conditions. This modification will be carried out in a couple steps, where we initially work only with lengths â„“uâ¢vsubscriptâ„“ğ‘¢ğ‘£\ell_{uv}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of edges (u,v)âˆˆEğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ¸(u,v)\in E( italic_u , italic_v ) âˆˆ italic_E, and eventually let Î´â€²superscriptğ›¿â€²\delta^{\prime}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the metric induced by shortest-path distances.

For every s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T define the interval Î“sâ¢t:=[Îµâ¢dsâ¢t,dsâ¢t]assignsubscriptÎ“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğœ€subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\Gamma_{st}:=[\varepsilon d_{st},d_{st}]roman_Î“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ italic_Îµ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and let Î“={0}âˆª(âˆªs,tâˆˆTÎ“sâ¢t)Î“0subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptÎ“ğ‘ ğ‘¡\Gamma=\{0\}\cup\Big{(}\cup_{s,t\in T}\Gamma_{st}\Big{)}roman_Î“ = { 0 } âˆª ( âˆª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and let Î“ÎµsuperscriptÎ“ğœ€\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contain 00 and all powers of (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ) that lie in Î“Î“\Gammaroman_Î“. The following claim provides structural information about a â€œniceâ€ near-optimal solution.

Claim 4.4.

    are dominated by lğ‘™litalic_l (namely, âˆ€tâˆˆNâ¢(v),â„“^vâ¢tâ‰¤â„“vâ¢tformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘£subscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\forall t\in N(v),\ \widehat{\ell}_{vt}\leq\ell_{vt}âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ italic_N ( italic_v ) , over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT);

    use values only from Î“ÎµsuperscriptÎ“ğœ€\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (namely, âˆ€tâˆˆNâ¢(v),â„“^vâ¢tâˆˆÎ“Îµformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘£subscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡superscriptÎ“ğœ€\forall t\in N(v),\ \widehat{\ell}_{vt}\in\Gamma^{\varepsilon}âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ italic_N ( italic_v ) , over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT); and

  • â€¢

    satisfy 1+Îµ(1âˆ’Îµ)21ğœ€superscript1ğœ€2\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG-relaxed shortest distance constraints (namely, âˆ€s,tâˆˆT,â„“^sâ¢v+â„“^vâ¢tâ‰¥(1âˆ’Îµ)21+Îµâ¢Î´sâ¢tformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscript^â„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€21ğœ€subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ ğ‘¡\forall s,t\in T,\ \widehat{\ell}_{sv}+\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}\delta_{st}âˆ€ italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T , over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Proof.

Let every edge length â„“^vâ¢tsubscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\widehat{\ell}_{vt}over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be defined as â„“vâ¢tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\ell_{vt}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rounded down to its nearest value from Î“ÎµsuperscriptÎ“ğœ€\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The first two claimed properties then hold by construction. For the third property, recall that lğ‘™litalic_l is a feasible LP solution, thus â„“sâ¢v+â„“vâ¢tâ‰¥dsâ¢tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\ell_{sv}+\ell_{vt}\geq d_{st}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Assume without loss of generality that â„“sâ¢vâ‰¤â„“vâ¢tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\ell_{sv}\leq\ell_{vt}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the large one â„“vâ¢tâ‰¥(1âˆ’Îµ)2â¢dsâ¢tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€2subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\ell_{vt}\geq(1-\varepsilon)^{2}d_{st}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the claim follows because also â„“^vâ¢tâ‰¥(1âˆ’Îµ)21+Îµâ¢dsâ¢tsubscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€21ğœ€subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}d_{st}over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, regardless of whether â„“vâ¢tsubscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\ell_{vt}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is smaller or bigger than dsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the extra term of (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ) comes from rounding down to the nearest power of (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_Îµ ).
