The fact that Îµ<18ğœ€18\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}italic_Îµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG means Îµâ¢(2âˆ’Îµ)â¢1+Îµâ‰¥1ğœ€2ğœ€1ğœ€1{\varepsilon(2-\varepsilon)}{1+\varepsilon}\geq 1italic_Îµ ( 2 - italic_Îµ ) 1 + italic_Îµ â‰¥ 1, so rounding down does not zero out â„“^sâ¢vsubscript^â„“ğ‘ ğ‘£\widehat{\ell}_{sv}over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We conclude that the new lengths are at least 11+Îµ11ğœ€\frac{1}{1+\varepsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG times the old ones, namely â„“^sâ¢vâ‰¥â„“sâ¢v1+Îµsubscript^â„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptâ„“ğ‘ ğ‘£1ğœ€\widehat{\ell}_{sv}\geq\frac{\ell_{sv}}{1+\varepsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG and â„“^vâ¢tâ‰¥â„“vâ¢t1+Îµsubscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡1ğœ€\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{\ell_{vt}}{1+\varepsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG. The claim follows. âˆ

We proceed with the proof of Theorem 4.3. Define new edge lengths {â„“eâ€²:eâˆˆE}conditional-setsubscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘’ğ‘’ğ¸\{\ell^{\prime}_{e}:e\in E\}{ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_e âˆˆ italic_E } by applying the claim and scaling edge lengths by 1+Îµ(1âˆ’Îµ)21ğœ€superscript1ğœ€2\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, namely for every vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡v\in V\setminus Titalic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T, and an adjacent tâˆˆTğ‘¡ğ‘‡t\in Titalic_t âˆˆ italic_T, set â„“vâ¢tâ€²:=1+Îµ(1âˆ’Îµ)2â¢â„“^vâ¢tassignsubscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘£ğ‘¡1ğœ€superscript1ğœ€2subscript^â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡\ell^{\prime}_{vt}:=\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}\,\widehat{\ell}_{vt}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG over^ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This scaling and the third property of ClaimÂ 4.4 ensures that the shortest-path distances (using edge lengths â„“eâ€²subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘’\ell^{\prime}_{e}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) between each pair of vertices i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j is at least Î´iâ¢jsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘—\delta_{ij}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Now partition the non-terminals into buckets, where two non-terminals u,vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡u,v\in V\setminus Titalic_u , italic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T are in the same bucket if they â€œagreeâ€ about each of their neighbors tâˆˆTğ‘¡ğ‘‡t\in Titalic_t âˆˆ italic_T: either (i) they are both non-adjacent to tğ‘¡titalic_t, or (ii) they are both adjacent to tğ‘¡titalic_t and â„“uâ¢tâ€²=â„“vâ¢tâ€²subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘£ğ‘¡\ell^{\prime}_{ut}=\ell^{\prime}_{vt}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Observe that this bucketing is indeed a well-defined equivalence relation. Now for every u,vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡u,v\in V\setminus Titalic_u , italic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T that are the same bucket, add an edge of length â„“uâ¢vâ€²=0subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘¢ğ‘£0\ell^{\prime}_{uv}=0roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and let Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote this set of new edges. Let Î´â€²superscriptğ›¿â€²\delta^{\prime}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the shortest-path distances according to these new edge-lengths. Observe that the shortest-path distances between the terminals are unchanged by the addition of these new zero-length edges, even though the distances between some non-terminals have obviously changed. Hence (â„“eâ€²,Î´iâ¢jâ€²)subscriptsuperscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—(\ell^{\prime}_{e},\delta^{\prime}_{ij})( roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a feasible solution toÂ (LP1), with objective function value at most 1+Îµ(1âˆ’Îµ)2â¢Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤(1+5â¢Îµ)â¢Î»Gâ¢(ğ)1ğœ€superscript1ğœ€2subscriptğœ†ğºğ15ğœ€subscriptğœ†ğºğ\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq(1+5\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})divide start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ ( 1 + 5 italic_Îµ ) italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ).

We define the equivalence classes of the bucketing above as the sets Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in PropositionÂ 4.2. Each bucket corresponds to a â€œprofileâ€ vector with kğ‘˜kitalic_k coordinates that represent the lengths of kğ‘˜kitalic_k edges going to the kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals, if at all there is an edge to the terminals. Each coordinate of this profile vector is an element of Î“ÎµsuperscriptÎ“ğœ€\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Î“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or it represents the corresponding edge does not exist. It follows that the number of buckets (or profile vectors) is mâ‰¤((k2)â¢(log1+Îµâ¡1Îµ+3))kâ‰¤(Oâ¢(k2Îµâ¢logâ¡1Îµ))kâ‰¤(Oâ¢(kÎµ))2â¢kâ‰¤expâ¡{Oâ¢(kâ¢logâ¡(k/Îµ))}ğ‘šsuperscriptbinomialğ‘˜2subscript1ğœ€1ğœ€3ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğœ€1ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğœ€2ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğœ€m\leq\Big{(}\binom{k}{2}(\log_{1+\varepsilon}\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}+3)\Big{)}^{k}\leq(O(\tfrac{k^{2}}{\varepsilon}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}))^{k}\leq(O(\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}))^{2k}\leq\exp\{{O(k\log(k/\varepsilon))}\}italic_m â‰¤ ( ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG + 3 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_k / italic_Îµ ) ) }. The theorem follows by applying Proposition 4.2, which asserts the existence of a flow-sparsifier with m(Îµâˆ’1â¢logâ¡k)k2â‰¤expâ¡{Oâ¢(kâ¢logâ¡kÎµâ¢(1Îµâ¢logâ¡k)k2)}superscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsuperscriptğœ€1ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğœ€superscript1ğœ€ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜2m^{(\varepsilon^{-1}\log k)^{k^{2}}}\leq\exp\{O(k\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)^{k^{2}})\}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } vertices. âˆ

5 The Splicing and Composition Techniques

We say that a path is terminal-free if all its internal vertices are non-terminals. This terminology shall be used mostly for flow paths, in which the pathsâ€™ endpoints are certainly terminals. The lemma below refers to two different methods of routing a demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d in a network GğºGitalic_G. The first method is the usual (and default) meaning, where the demand is routed along arbitrary flow paths. The second method is to route the demand along terminal-free flow paths, and we will say this explicitly whenever we refer to this method. We use a parameter Ïâ‰¥1ğœŒ1\rho\geq 1italic_Ï â‰¥ 1 to achieve greater generality, although the case Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1italic_Ï = 1 conveys the main idea.

Lemma 5.1 (Splicing Lemma).

Let Gasubscriptğºğ‘G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two networks having the same set of terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, and fix Ïâ‰¥1ğœŒ1\rho\geq 1italic_Ï â‰¥ 1. Suppose that whenever a demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d between terminals in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T can be routed in Gasubscriptğºğ‘G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using terminal-free flow paths, demand ğ/ÏğğœŒ\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_Ï can be routed in Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (by arbitrary flow paths). Then for every demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d between terminals in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T that can be routed in Gasubscriptğºğ‘G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, demand ğ/ÏğğœŒ\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_Ï can be routed in Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Consider a demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that is routed in Gasubscriptğºğ‘G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using flow f*superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let us show that it can be routed also in Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fix for f*superscriptğ‘“f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a flow decomposition D={(P1,Ï•â¢(P1)),(P2,Ï•â¢(P2)),â€¦}ğ·subscriptğ‘ƒ1italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ƒ2â€¦D=\{(P_{1},\phi(P_{1})),(P_{2},\phi(P_{2})),\ldots\}italic_D = { ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , â€¦ } for it, where each Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a terminal-to-terminal path, and Ï•â¢(Pl)italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\phi(P_{l})italic_Ï• ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the amount of flow sent on this path. A flow decomposition also specifies the demand vector since dsâ¢t=âˆ‘sâ¢t-pathsÂ PâˆˆDÏ•â¢(P)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsâ¢t-pathsÂ PâˆˆDitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒd_{st}=\sum_{\text{$st$-paths $P\in D$}}\phi(P)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t -paths italic_P âˆˆ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( italic_P ). If all the paths (P,Ï•)âˆˆDğ‘ƒitalic-Ï•ğ·(P,\phi)\in D( italic_P , italic_Ï• ) âˆˆ italic_D are terminal-free, then we know by the assumption of the lemma that demand ğ/ÏğğœŒ\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_Ï can be routed in Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Else, take a path (P,Ï•)âˆˆDğ‘ƒitalic-Ï•ğ·(P,\phi)\in D( italic_P , italic_Ï• ) âˆˆ italic_D that contains internally some terminalâ€”say Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P routes flow between terminals tâ€²,tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and uses another terminal sğ‘ sitalic_s internally. We may assume without loss of generality that the flow paths are simple, so sâˆ‰{tâ€²,tâ€²â€²}ğ‘ superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²s\not\in\{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}\}italic_s âˆ‰ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. We replace the flow (P,Ï•â¢(P))ğ‘ƒitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒ(P,\phi(P))( italic_P , italic_Ï• ( italic_P ) ) in ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d by the two paths (Pâ¢[tâ€²,s],Ï•)ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘ italic-Ï•(P[t^{\prime},s],\phi)( italic_P [ italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s ] , italic_Ï• ) and (Pâ¢[s,tâ€²â€²],Ï•)ğ‘ƒğ‘ superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²italic-Ï•(P[s,t^{\prime\prime}],\phi)( italic_P [ italic_s , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , italic_Ï• ) to get a new flow decomposition Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and denote the corresponding demand vector by ğâ€²superscriptğâ€²\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that dtâ€²,tâ€²â€²â€²=dtâ€²,tâ€²â€²âˆ’Ï•subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²subscriptğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²italic-Ï•d^{\prime}_{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}}=d_{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}}-\phiitalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ï•, whereas dtâ€²,sâ€²=dtâ€²,s+Ï•subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘ italic-Ï•d^{\prime}_{t^{\prime},s}=d_{t^{\prime},s}+\phiitalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ï• and the same for ds,tâ€²â€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²d^{\prime}_{s,t^{\prime\prime}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, if ğâ€²/Ïsuperscriptğâ€²ğœŒ\mathbf{d}^{\prime}/\rhobold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Ï can be routed on some graph Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with an arbitrary routing, we can connect together Ï•/Ïitalic-Ï•ğœŒ\phi/\rhoitalic_Ï• / italic_Ï amount of the flow from tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to sğ‘ sitalic_s with Ï•/Ïitalic-Ï•ğœŒ\phi/\rhoitalic_Ï• / italic_Ï flow from sğ‘ sitalic_s to tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to get a feasible routing for ğ/ÏğğœŒ\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_Ï in Gbsubscriptğºğ‘G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover the total number of terminals occurring internally on paths in the flow decomposition Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is less than that in ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, so the proof follows by a simple induction. âˆ

The next lemma addresses the case where our network can be described as the gluing of two networks G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and we already have sparsifiers for G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; in this case, we can simply glue together the two sparsifiers, provided that the vertices at the gluing locations are themselves terminals. Formally, let G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be networks on disjoint sets of vertices, having terminal sets T1={s1,s2,â€¦,sa}subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘T_{1}=\{s_{1},s_{2},\ldots,s_{a}\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and T2={t1,t2,â€¦,tb}subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘T_{2}=\{t_{1},t_{2},\ldots,t_{b}\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } respectively. Given a bijection Ï•:={s1â†”t1,â€¦,scâ†”tc}\phi:=\{s_{1}\leftrightarrow t_{1},\ldots,s_{c}\leftrightarrow t_{c}\}italic_Ï• := { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†” italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†” italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } between some subset of T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•-merge of G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (denoted G1âŠ•Ï•G2subscriptdirect-sumitalic-Ï•subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is the graph formed by identifying the vertices sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iâˆˆ[c]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[c]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_c ]. Note that the set of terminals in GğºGitalic_G is T:=T1âˆª{tc+1,â€¦,tb}assignğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘T:=T_{1}\cup\{t_{c+1},\ldots,t_{b}\}italic_T := italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

Lemma 5.2 (Composition Lemma).

Suppose G=G1âŠ•Ï•G2ğºsubscriptdirect-sumitalic-Ï•subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G=G_{1}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}italic_G = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For jâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘—12j\in\{1,2\}italic_j âˆˆ { 1 , 2 }, let Gjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğºnormal-â€²ğ‘—G^{\prime}_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a flow-sparsifier for Gjsubscriptğºğ‘—G_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with quality ÏjsubscriptğœŒğ‘—\rho_{j}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the graph Gâ€²=G1â€²âŠ•Ï•G2â€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²subscriptdirect-sumitalic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğº1normal-â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2normal-â€²G^{\prime}=G_{1}^{\prime}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a quality maxâ¡{Ï1,Ï2}subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}roman_max { italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } flow sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G.

Proof.

Consider a demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that is routable in GğºGitalic_G using flow paths that do not have internal terminals. Since GğºGitalic_G is formed by gluing G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at terminals, this means each of the flow paths lies entirely within G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write ğ=ğ1+ğ2ğsubscriptğ1subscriptğ2\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2}bold_d = bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where each ğjsubscriptğğ‘—\mathbf{d}_{j}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the demand being routed on the flow paths among these that lie within Gjsubscriptğºğ‘—G_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the definition of flow-sparsifiers, these demands are also routable in G1â€²,G2â€²superscriptsubscriptğº1â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2â€²G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively, and hence demand ğ1+ğ2=ğsubscriptğ1subscriptğ2ğ\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2}=\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_d is routable in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (in fact by paths that lie entirely within G1subscriptğº1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or G2subscriptğº2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Applying the Splicing Lemma (with Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1italic_Ï = 1), we get that every demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d routable in GğºGitalic_G is routable also in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The argument in the other direction is similar. Assume ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d is routable in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using terminal-free flow paths; then we get two demands ğ1,ğ2subscriptğ1subscriptğ2\mathbf{d}_{1},\mathbf{d}_{2}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT routable entirely in G1â€²,G2â€²superscriptsubscriptğº1â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2â€²G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. Scaling these demands down by maxâ¡{Ï1,Ï2}subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}roman_max { italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, they can be routed in G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively, and hence we can route their sum (ğ1+ğ2)/maxâ¡{Ï1,Ï2}subscriptğ1subscriptğ2subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2(\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2})/\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}( bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_max { italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in GğºGitalic_G. Applying the Splicing Lemma with Ï=maxâ¡{Ï1,Ï2}ğœŒsubscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2\rho=\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}italic_Ï = roman_max { italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, we get a similar conclusion for all demands routable in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (on arbitrary flow paths), and this completes the proof. âˆ

Applications of Splicing/Composition.

The Splicing and Composition Lemmas will be useful in many of our arguments: we use them to show a singly-exponential bound for quasi-bipartite graphs in SectionÂ 5.1 below, in the sampling approach for quasi-bipartite graphs in Section 6, and also in constructing flow-sparsifiers for series parallel and bounded treewidth graphs in SectionÂ 7.

5.1 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs via Splicing

We show how to use Splicing Lemma 5.1 to construct a flow sparsifier for the quasi-bipartite graph of size (1/Îµ)O~â¢(k)superscript1ğœ€~ğ‘‚ğ‘˜(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}( 1 / italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Theorem 5.3.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, and let Îµâˆˆ(0,18)ğœ€018\varepsilon\in(0,{\tfrac{1}{8}})italic_Îµ âˆˆ ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ). Then GğºGitalic_G admits a quality 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ flow-sparsifier G^normal-^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG of size (1/Îµ)O~â¢(k)superscript1ğœ€normal-~ğ‘‚ğ‘˜(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}( 1 / italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

The construction goes through several stages. First, we construct Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by rounding down the capacity to an integer power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ. The main idea is to define â€œtypesâ€ for non-terminals vğ‘£vitalic_v and then merge all vertices of the same type (i.e., the new edge capacity is the sum of the respective edge capacities incident to the merged vertices). The main difficulty is in defining the types.

To define the type, first of all partition all non-terminals vğ‘£vitalic_v into â€œsuper-typesâ€, according to the set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of terminals that are connected to vğ‘£vitalic_v by edges with non-zero capacity. We will repeat the above procedure for the next suffix of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r until we are done routing flow Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that we have at most kğ‘˜kitalic_k such stages.

We need to mention one more aspect in the above argument â€” what happens to the flow that is contributed to edges (tiâ€²,vj)subscriptğ‘¡superscriptğ‘–â€²subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—(t_{i^{\prime}},v_{j})( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where iâ€²â‰¤isuperscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘–i^{\prime}\leq iitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_i? Since we left a slack of Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ in the capacity for each edge in the above argument, we still satisfy the capacity constraint overall for each edge.

Finally, to argue about the size of G^^ğº\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, note that there are only 2ksuperscript2ğ‘˜2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT super-types, and there are at most Oâ¢(k2/Îµ)kğ‘‚superscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜2ğœ€ğ‘˜O(k^{2}/\varepsilon)^{k}italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible vectors rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, and hence G^^ğº\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG has size at most Oâ¢(2kâ‹…Oâ¢(k2/Îµ)k)=(1/Îµ)O~â¢(k)ğ‘‚â‹…superscript2ğ‘˜ğ‘‚superscriptsuperscriptğ‘˜2ğœ€ğ‘˜superscript1ğœ€~ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(2^{k}\cdot O(k^{2}/\varepsilon)^{k})=(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}italic_O ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ( 1 / italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. âˆ

6 A Sampling Approach for Flow Sparsifiers

In this section we develop our sampling approach to construct flow sparsifiers. In particular, for quasi-bipartite graphs we construct in this method flow sparsifiers of size bounded by a polynomial in k/Îµğ‘˜ğœ€k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_Îµ. This family includes the graphs for which a lower bound (for exact cut/flow sparsification) was proved in [KR13], and we further discuss how our construction extends to include also the graphs for which a lower bound was proved in [KRTV12].

6.1 Preliminaries

We say that a random variable is deterministic if it has variance 00 (i.e., it attains one specific value with probability 1111).

Theorem 6.1 (A Chernoff Variant).

Let X1,â€¦,Xmâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘‹1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘š0X_{1},\ldots,X_{m}\geq 0italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 be independent random variables, such that each Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is either deterministic or Xiâˆˆ[0,b]subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–0ğ‘X_{i}\in[0,b]italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_b ], and let X=âˆ‘i=1mXiğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X=\sum_{i=1}^{m}X_{i}italic_X = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then

Prâ¡[Xâ‰¤(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğ”¼[X]]Prğ‘‹1ğœ€ğ”¼ğ‘‹\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}X\leq(1-\varepsilon)\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]\Big{]}roman_Pr [ italic_X â‰¤ ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) blackboard_E [ italic_X ] ] â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢ğ”¼[X]/(2â¢b),absentsuperscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğ”¼ğ‘‹2ğ‘\displaystyle\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]/(2b)},â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_X ] / ( 2 italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€Îµâˆˆ(0,1),for-allğœ€01\displaystyle\forall\varepsilon\in(0,1),âˆ€ italic_Îµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) ,
Prâ¡[Xâ‰¥(1+Îµ)â¢ğ”¼[X]]Prğ‘‹1ğœ€ğ”¼ğ‘‹\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}X\geq(1+\varepsilon)\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]\Big{]}roman_Pr [ italic_X â‰¥ ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) blackboard_E [ italic_X ] ] â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢ğ”¼[X]/(3â¢b),absentsuperscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğ”¼ğ‘‹3ğ‘\displaystyle\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]/(3b)},â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_X ] / ( 3 italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€Îµâˆˆ(0,1).for-allğœ€01\displaystyle\forall\varepsilon\in(0,1).âˆ€ italic_Îµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) .
Proof.

First, replace every deterministic Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with multiple random variables that are still deterministic but are all in the range [0,b]0ğ‘[0,b][ 0 , italic_b ]. It suffices to prove the deviation bounds for the new summation, because the new variables trivially maintain the independence condition, and the deviation bound does not depend on the number mğ‘šmitalic_m of random variables.

Assuming now that every random variable is in the range [0,b]0ğ‘[0,b][ 0 , italic_b ], the deviation bounds follow from standard Chernoff bounds [MR95, DP09] by scaling all the random variables by factor 1/b1ğ‘1/b1 / italic_b. âˆ

6.2 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs

Recall that a quasi-bipartite graph is one where the non-terminals form an independent set; i.e., there are no edges between non-terminals.

Theorem 6.2.

Let G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network, and let 0<Îµ<180ğœ€180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_Îµ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG. Then GğºGitalic_G admits a quality 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ flow-sparsifier G^normal-^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG that has at most O~â¢(k7/Îµ3)normal-~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜7superscriptğœ€3\tilde{O}(k^{7}/\varepsilon^{3})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) vertices.

Our algorithm is randomized, and is based on importance sampling, as follows. Throughout, let TâŠ‚Vğ‘‡ğ‘‰T\subset Vitalic_T âŠ‚ italic_V be the set of kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals, and assume the graph is connected. We may assume without loss of generality that Tğ‘‡Titalic_T also forms an independent set, by subdividing every edge that connects two terminals (i.e., replacing it with a length 2222 path whose edges have the same capacities as the edge being replaced). We use a parameter M:=Câ¢Îµâˆ’3â¢k5â¢logâ¡(1Îµâ¢logâ¡k)assignğ‘€ğ¶superscriptğœ€3superscriptğ‘˜51ğœ€ğ‘˜M:=C\varepsilon^{-3}k^{5}\log(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)italic_M := italic_C italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log italic_k ), where C>0ğ¶0C>0italic_C > 0 is a sufficiently large constant.

  1. 1.

    For every s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T, compute a maximum sâ¢tğ‘ ğ‘¡stitalic_s italic_t-flow in GğºGitalic_G along 2-hops paths. These path are edge-disjoint and each is identified by its middle vertex, this flow is given by

(6.7)
  2. 2.

For the sake of analysis, it will be convenient to replace step 3 with the following step, which is obviously equivalent in terms of flow.

Lemma 6.3.

Lemma 6.4.

Observe that Theorem 6.2 follows immediately from Lemmas 6.3 and 6.4. It remains to prove the latter lemma, and we do this next. We remark that the 0.90.90.90.9 probabilities above are arbitrary, and can be easily improved to be 1âˆ’oâ¢(1)1ğ‘œ11-o(1)1 - italic_o ( 1 ).

6.2.1 Proving the Lower Bound (6.9)

The plan for proving (6.9) is to discretize the set of all demand vectors, show a deviation bound for each of these demands (separately), and then apply a union bound. We will thus need the next lemma, which shows that for every fixed demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that (satisfies some technical conditions and) is feasible in GğºGitalic_G, with high probabilityÂ a slightly scaled demand (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğ1ğœ€ğ(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_Îµ ) bold_d is feasible in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

Given a demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, the problem of concurrent flow along 2-hop paths can be written as linear program (LP3). It has variables fvsâ¢tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£f^{st}_{v}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing flow along a path sâˆ’vâˆ’tğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘¡s-v-titalic_s - italic_v - italic_t, for the commodity s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T and intermediate non-terminal vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡v\in V\setminus Titalic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T. Let NGâ¢(w)subscriptğ‘ğºğ‘¤N_{G}(w)italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) denote the set of neighbors of vertex wğ‘¤witalic_w in the graph GğºGitalic_G.

Lemma 6.5.

Fix Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 and ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 } such that (i) demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths, and (ii) every nonzero coordinate dsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d is a power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ in the range [Î·â¢Fsâ¢t,Fsâ¢t]ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].333The range upper bound Fsâ¢tsubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡F_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows anyway from requirementÂ (i). We also remark that the requirement about power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ is not necessary for the lemmaâ€™s proof, but for later use, it is convenient to include it here. Then

Prâ¡[demandÂ (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğÂ admits a flow inÂ G^Â alongÂ 2-hop paths]â‰¥1âˆ’(k2)â¢eâˆ’Îµ2â¢Î·â¢M/2.PrdemandÂ (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğÂ admits a flow inÂ G^Â alongÂ 2-hop paths1binomialğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğœ‚ğ‘€2\Pr[\text{demand $(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}$ admits a flow in ${\smash{\widehat{G}}}$ along $2$-hop paths}]\geq 1-\textstyle\binom{k}{2}\,e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}.roman_Pr [ demand ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) bold_d admits a flow in over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2 -hop paths ] â‰¥ 1 - ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Proof.

Given demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, fix a flow fğ‘“fitalic_f that satisfies it in GğºGitalic_G along 2222-hop paths. Thus, fsâ¢t=dsâ¢tâ‰¥Î·â¢Fsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡f_{st}=d_{st}\geq\eta F_{st}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG be the graph constructed using the above randomized procedure, and recall that random variable Ivsubscriptğ¼ğ‘£I_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an indicator for the event that non-terminal vğ‘£vitalic_v is sampled in step 3â€™, which happens independently with probability p~vsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘£\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Define a flow f^^ğ‘“{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG in the natural way: scale every flow-path in fğ‘“fitalic_f whose intermediate vertex is vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡v\in V\setminus Titalic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T by the corresponding Iv/p~vsubscriptğ¼ğ‘£subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting flow f^^ğ‘“{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG is indeed feasible in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths. It remains to prove that with high probabilityÂ this flow f^^ğ‘“{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG routes at least (i.e., a demand that dominates) (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğ1ğœ€ğ(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_Îµ ) bold_d.

Fix a demand pair (commodity) s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T. (6.11)

By linearity of expectation, ğ”¼[f^sâ¢t]=âˆ‘vfvsâ¢tâ‹…ğ”¼[Iv]/p~v=âˆ‘vfvsâ¢t=fsâ¢tğ”¼superscript^ğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ”¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘£subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}]=\sum_{v}f^{st}_{v}\cdot\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[I_{v}]/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}=\sum_{v}f^{st}_{v}=f^{st}blackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… blackboard_E [ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. fvsâ¢tâ‹…Iv/p~vâ‰¤fvsâ¢t/p~vâ‰¤Fsâ¢t,v/pvâ‰¤Fsâ¢t/M.â‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£subscriptğ¼ğ‘£subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘€f^{st}_{v}\cdot I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\leq f^{st}_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\leq F_{st,v}/p_{v}\leq F_{st}/M.italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_M .

Applying Theorem 6.1, we obtain, as required,

Prâ¡[f^sâ¢tâ‰¤(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢fsâ¢t]â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢fsâ¢t/(2â¢Fsâ¢t/M)â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢Î·â¢M/2.Prsuperscript^ğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€superscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2superscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘¡2subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘€superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğœ‚ğ‘€2\Pr[{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}\leq(1-\varepsilon)f^{st}]\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}f^{st}/(2F_{st}/M)}\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}.roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

A straightforward union bound over the (k2)binomialğ‘˜2\binom{k}{2}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) choices of s,tğ‘ ğ‘¡s,titalic_s , italic_t completes the proof of LemmaÂ 6.5. âˆ

We proceed now to prove (6.9) using Lemma 6.5.

Proof of Eqn.Â (6.9).

Applying Lemma 6.5 to each dâˆˆğ’ŸLâ¢Bğ‘‘superscriptğ’Ÿğ¿ğµd\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}italic_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and using a union bound, we get that with probability at least 1âˆ’|ğ’ŸLâ¢B|â‹…(k2)â¢eâˆ’Îµ2â¢Î·â¢M/2â‰¥0.91â‹…superscriptğ’Ÿğ¿ğµbinomialğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğœ‚ğ‘€20.91-\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}\rvert\cdot\binom{k}{2}e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}\geq 0.91 - | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‹… ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.9, for every dâˆˆğ’ŸLâ¢Bğ‘‘superscriptğ’Ÿğ¿ğµd\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}italic_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢d1ğœ€ğ‘‘(1-\varepsilon)d( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_d can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. We assume henceforth this high-probability event indeed occurs, and show how this assumption implies the event described in (6.9).

To this end, fix a demand vector ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 }, and let us prove that Î»G^â¢(ğ)â‰¥(1âˆ’3â¢Îµ)â¢Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†^ğºğ13ğœ€subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq(1-3\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ ( 1 - 3 italic_Îµ ) italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). We can make two simplifying assumptions about the demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, both of which are without loss of generality. Firstly, we assume that Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¥1subscriptğœ†ğºğ1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ 1, i.e., demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G, because event inÂ (6.9) is invariant under scaling of ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d. Secondly, we assume that ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by 2222-hop flow paths; if each such demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^ğº\widehat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG with congestion at most 1/(1âˆ’3â¢Îµ)113ğœ€1/(1-3\varepsilon)1 / ( 1 - 3 italic_Îµ ), then LemmaÂ 5.1 implies that every demand satisfiable in GğºGitalic_G (without the restriction to 2222-hop paths) can be satisfied in G^^ğº\widehat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG with the same congestion.

So consider a demand ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 }, such that Î»Gâ¢(ğ)=1subscriptğœ†ğºğ1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})=1italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) = 1 and ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by 2-hop flow paths. Let ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d by zeroing every coordinate dsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is smaller than 2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢t2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡2\eta\,F_{st}2 italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This vector can be written as ğâˆ’=ğâˆ’âˆ‘sâ¢tÎ±sâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tsuperscriptğğsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathbf{d}^{-}=\mathbf{d}-\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_d - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğsâ¢tâˆˆâ„+(T2)subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡2\mathbf{e}_{st}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the standard basis vector for pair (s,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¡(s,t)( italic_s , italic_t ), and Î±sâ¢t:=dsâ¢tassignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\alpha_{st}:=d_{st}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if this value is smaller than 2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢t2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and zero otherwise. Rounding each nonzero coordinate of ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT down to the next power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ yields a demand vector ğLâ¢Bâˆˆğ’ŸLâ¢Bsuperscriptğğ¿ğµsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ¿ğµ\mathbf{d}^{LB}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and thus by our earlier assumption, (1âˆ’Îµ)â¢ğLâ¢Bâ‰¥1âˆ’Îµ1+Îµâ¢ğâˆ’1ğœ€superscriptğğ¿ğµ1ğœ€1ğœ€superscriptğ(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{LB}\geq\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}\mathbf{d}^{-}( 1 - italic_Îµ ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. For each s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T, consider the demand vector Fsâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tsubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By rounding its single nonzero coordinate down to the next power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ, we obtain a vector in ğ’ŸLâ¢Bsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ¿ğµ{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence we conclude that 1âˆ’Îµ1+Îµâ¢Fsâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢t1ğœ€1ğœ€subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. The set of demands satisfiable by 2-hop flow paths in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is clearly convex, so taking a combination of such demand vectors with coefficients that add up to (1âˆ’Îµ)+âˆ‘s,tâˆˆTÎ±sâ¢tFsâ¢tâ‰¤(1âˆ’Îµ)+k22â‹…2â¢Î·=11ğœ€subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€â‹…superscriptğ‘˜222ğœ‚1(1-\varepsilon)+\sum_{s,t\in T}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\leq(1-\varepsilon)+\tfrac{k^{2}}{2}\cdot 2\eta=1( 1 - italic_Îµ ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) + divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‹… 2 italic_Î· = 1, we conclude that

(1âˆ’Îµ)â‹…1âˆ’Îµ1+Îµâ¢ğâˆ’+âˆ‘sâ¢tÎ±sâ¢tFsâ¢tâ‹…1âˆ’Îµ1+Îµâ¢Fsâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tâ‰¥(1âˆ’Îµ)21+Îµâ¢[ğâˆ’+âˆ‘sâ¢tÎ±sâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢t]â‰¥(1âˆ’3â¢Îµ)â¢ğâ‹…1ğœ€1ğœ€1ğœ€superscriptğsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€1ğœ€subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€21ğœ€delimited-[]superscriptğsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡13ğœ€ğ(1-\varepsilon)\cdot\tfrac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}\,\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\cdot\tfrac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\geq\tfrac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}\Big{[}\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\Big{]}\geq(1-3\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_Îµ ) â‹… divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Îµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG [ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¥ ( 1 - 3 italic_Îµ ) bold_d

can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. This implies that Î»G^â¢(ğ)â‰¥1âˆ’3â¢Îµsubscriptğœ†^ğºğ13ğœ€\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1-3\varepsilonitalic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ 1 - 3 italic_Îµ, which completes the proof of (6.9). âˆ

6.2.2 Proving the Upper Bound (6.10)

The plan for proving (6.10) is similar, i.e., to prove a deviation bound for every demand in a small discrete set and then apply a union bound. However, we need to bound the deviation in the opposite direction, and thus use the LP that is dual to flow (which can be viewed as â€œfractional cutâ€). We will need a statement of the following form: for every fixed demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that (satisfies some technical conditions and) is not feasible in GğºGitalic_G, with high probabilityÂ the slightly further scaled-up demand (1+Îµ)â¢ğ1ğœ€ğ(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_Îµ ) bold_d is not feasible in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. The next lemma proves such a statement, except that it considers only flow along 2222-hop paths, and that ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d is scaled by another 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ factor.

Lemma 6.6.

Fix Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 and let ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 } be a demand vector such that (i) demand (1+Îµ)â¢ğ1ğœ€ğ(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_Îµ ) bold_d cannot be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by flow along 2-hop paths, and (ii) every nonzero coordinate dsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ in the range [Î·â¢Fsâ¢t,Fsâ¢t]ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].444Again, the power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ requirement is not really necessary to prove the lemma, and will be needed only later. But by introducing it right now, we avoid having two versions of condition (ii). Then

Prâ¡[demandÂ (1+Îµ)2â¢ğÂ admits a flow inÂ G^Â alongÂ 2-hop flow paths]â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢Î·â¢M/k2.PrdemandÂ (1+Îµ)2â¢ğÂ admits a flow inÂ G^Â alongÂ 2-hop flow pathssuperscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğœ‚ğ‘€superscriptğ‘˜2\Pr[\text{demand $(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\mathbf{d}$ admits a flow in ${\smash{\widehat{G}}}$ along $2$-hop flow paths}]\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/k^{2}}.roman_Pr [ demand ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_d admits a flow in over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2 -hop flow paths ] â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_M / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Our proof of Lemma 6.6 uses LP duality for flows along 2-hop paths, which we discuss first. Recall that for a given demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, our linear program (LP3) describes the problem of maximizing concurrent flow along 2222-hop paths. Its dual LP, written below, has variables â„“esubscriptâ„“ğ‘’\ell_{e}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the lengths of edges eâˆˆEğ‘’ğ¸e\in Eitalic_e âˆˆ italic_E, and variables ysâ¢tsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the distance (along the shortest 2-hop path) between s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T.

Lemma 6.7.

Let ysâ€²â¢tâ€²=1subscriptğ‘¦superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²1y_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}=1italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and for every vâˆˆNGâ¢(sâ€²)âˆ©NGâ¢(tâ€²)ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğºsuperscriptğ‘ â€²subscriptğ‘ğºsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²v\in N_{G}(s^{\prime})\cap N_{G}(t^{\prime})italic_v âˆˆ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), let one of the two edges (sâ€²,v)superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘£(s^{\prime},v)( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v ) and (v,tâ€²)ğ‘£superscriptğ‘¡â€²(v,t^{\prime})( italic_v , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), namely the one of cheaper cost have length 1111, and the other one have length 00 (breaking ties arbitrarily). Observing that the optimal LP value must be at least Fsâ€²â¢tâ€²subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because of weak LP duality and Lemma 6.7, we conclude that the constructed solution is indeed an optimal one. âˆ

Proof of Lemma 6.6.

Fix Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 and let ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 } be a demand vector satisfying the two requirements. We may assume that

âˆ€s,tâˆˆT,ifÂ dsâ¢t>0Â thenÂ Fsâ¢t>0,formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ifÂ dsâ¢t>0Â thenÂ Fsâ¢t>0\forall s,t\in T,\ \text{if $d_{st}>0$ then $F_{st}>0$},âˆ€ italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T , if italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 then italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 , (6.12)

as otherwise the demand cannot be satisfied and the lemmaâ€™s assertion holds trivially (the probability is 00). By requirement (i), the value of LP (LP3), and thus also of LP (LP4), is smaller than 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ. (6.13)

To prove a deviation bound on Z^^ğ‘\widehat{Z}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG using concentration from TheoremÂ 6.1, we need an upper bound on each term of the summation over vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s. The key insight is captured by the following claim.

Claim 6.9.

For every non-terminal vâˆˆVâˆ–Tğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡v\in V\setminus Titalic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T with p~v<1subscriptnormal-~ğ‘ğ‘£1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, its maximum contribution to zğ‘§zitalic_z is âˆ‘tâˆˆNGâ¢(v)cvâ¢tâ¢â„“vâ¢tâ‰¤p~vâ‹…k2/(2â¢Î·â¢M)subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğºğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptnormal-â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡normal-â‹…subscriptnormal-~ğ‘ğ‘£superscriptğ‘˜22ğœ‚ğ‘€\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}\leq\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\cdot k^{2}/(2\eta M)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 italic_Î· italic_M ).

Proof of Claim 6.9.

Fix vğ‘£vitalic_v with p~v<1subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, which implies pv=p~v<1subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£1p_{v}=\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1. â„“~e:={âˆ‘sâ€²,tâ€²:dsâ€²â¢tâ€²>0â„“esâ€²â¢tâ€²/(Î·â¢Fsâ€²â¢tâ€²)ifÂ eÂ is incident toÂ vÂ (inÂ G),â„“eotherwise.assignsubscript~â„“ğ‘’casessubscript:superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²subscriptğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²0subscriptsuperscriptâ„“superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘’ğœ‚subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ifÂ eÂ is incident toÂ vÂ (inÂ G),subscriptâ„“ğ‘’otherwise.\widetilde{\ell}_{e}:=\begin{cases}\sum_{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}:\ d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0}\ \ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}/(\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}})\quad&\text{if $e$ is incident to $v$ (in $G$),}\\ \ell_{e}&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}over~ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { start_ROW start_CELL âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_e is incident to italic_v (in italic_G ), end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW (6.14)

To verify this LP solution is feasible, we only need to check that ysâ¢tâ‰¤â„“~sâ¢v+â„“~vâ¢tsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscript~â„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscript~â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡y_{st}\leq\widetilde{\ell}_{sv}+\widetilde{\ell}_{vt}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ over~ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all s,tâˆˆNâ¢(v)ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘£s,t\in N(v)italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_N ( italic_v ). To this end, fix s,tâˆˆNâ¢(v)ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘£s,t\in N(v)italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_N ( italic_v ). We may assume that dsâ¢t>0subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡0d_{st}>0italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, as otherwise ysâ¢tsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be set to a large enough value without affecting the objective (strictly speaking, this modifies the LP also in some ysâ¢tsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT variables). We now have

Combining our last three estimates, we obtain

â„“~sâ¢v+â„“~vâ¢tâ‰¥ysâ¢tsâ¢t/(Î·â¢Fsâ¢t)=1/(Î·â¢Fsâ¢t)â‰¥ysâ¢t,subscript~â„“ğ‘ ğ‘£subscript~â„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¡\widetilde{\ell}_{sv}+\widetilde{\ell}_{vt}\geq y^{st}_{st}/(\eta F_{st})=1/(\eta F_{st})\geq y_{st},over~ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 / ( italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

which completes the verification that the modified LP solution is feasible.

We can now continue with the proof of Lemma 6.6 and prove the desired deviation bound on Z^^ğ‘\widehat{Z}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG. Recalling (6.13), we can write Z^=âˆ‘vâˆˆVâˆ–TZ^v^ğ‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘‡subscript^ğ‘ğ‘£\widehat{Z}=\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\widehat{Z}_{v}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_V âˆ– italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; each non-negative random variable Z^vsubscript^ğ‘ğ‘£\widehat{Z}_{v}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is either deterministic if p~v=1subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}=1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, or else p~v<1subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, in which case we apply Claim 6.9 to get the upper bound

Z^vâ‰¤(1/p~v)â¢âˆ‘tâˆˆNGâ¢(v)cvâ¢tâ¢â„“vâ¢tâ‰¤k2/(2â¢Î·â¢M).subscript^ğ‘ğ‘£1subscript~ğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğºğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptâ„“ğ‘£ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘˜22ğœ‚ğ‘€\widehat{Z}_{v}\leq(1/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v})\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}\leq k^{2}/(2\eta M).over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ ( 1 / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 italic_Î· italic_M ) .

Applying Theorem 6.1 and recalling that ğ”¼[Z^]=z<1+Îµğ”¼^ğ‘ğ‘§1ğœ€\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[\widehat{Z}]=z<1+\varepsilonblackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ] = italic_z < 1 + italic_Îµ, we have Prâ¡[Z^â‰¥(1+Îµ)2]â‰¤eâˆ’Îµ2â¢(1+Îµ)â¢Î·â¢M/k2Pr^ğ‘superscript1ğœ€2superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€21ğœ€ğœ‚ğ‘€superscriptğ‘˜2\Pr[\widehat{Z}\geq(1+\varepsilon)^{2}]\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}(1+\varepsilon)\eta M/k^{2}}roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG â‰¥ ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) italic_Î· italic_M / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which completes the proof of Lemma 6.6. âˆ

Proof of Eqn.Â (6.10).

The proof generally resembles that of (6.9), although several details are different and somewhat more complicated. Set Î·:=Îµ/k2assignğœ‚ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2\eta:=\varepsilon/k^{2}italic_Î· := italic_Îµ / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and define

ğ’ŸUâ¢B:={ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}Â that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in LemmaÂ 6.6}.assignsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}Â that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in LemmaÂ 6.6{\mathcal{D}}_{UB}:=\Big{\{}\text{$\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}$ that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma \ref{lem:samplingUBfixedDemand}}\Big{\}}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { dâˆˆR+(T2)âˆ–{0} that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma } . (6.15)

Then clearly |ğ’ŸUâ¢B|â‰¤(2+log1+Îµâ¡1Î·)(k2)â‰¤(1Îµâ¢logâ¡kÎµ)k2â‰¤(logâ¡kÎµ)Oâ¢(k2).superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµsuperscript2subscript1ğœ€1ğœ‚binomialğ‘˜2superscript1ğœ€ğ‘˜ğœ€superscriptğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘˜ğœ€ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}\rvert\leq\Big{(}2+\log_{1+\varepsilon}\tfrac{1}{\eta}\Big{)}^{\binom{k}{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{k^{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{\log k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{O(k^{2})}.| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‰¤ ( 2 + roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_Îµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_Îµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Applying Lemma 6.6 to each ğâˆˆğ’ŸUâ¢Bğsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a straightforward union bound, we see that with probability at least 1âˆ’|ğ’ŸUâ¢B|â‹…eâˆ’Îµ2â¢Î·â¢M/k2â‰¥0.91â‹…superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµsuperscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ€2ğœ‚ğ‘€superscriptğ‘˜20.91-\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}\rvert\cdot e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/k^{2}}\geq 0.91 - | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | â‹… italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_M / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.9, for every ğâˆˆğ’ŸUâ¢Bğsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that demand (1+Îµ)2â¢ğsuperscript1ğœ€2ğ(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\,\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_d cannot be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by flow along 2222-hop paths. We assume henceforth that this high-probability event indeed occurs, and show how this assumption implies the event in (6.10).

We thus aim to show that for every ğâˆˆâ„+(T2)âˆ–{0}ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„binomialğ‘‡20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { 0 } we have Î»G^â¢(ğ)â‰¤(1+4â¢Îµ)â¢Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†^ğºğ14ğœ€subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\leq(1+4\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ ( 1 + 4 italic_Îµ ) italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). By scaling ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d appropriately, it suffices to show that whenever Î»G^â¢(ğ)â‰¥1subscriptğœ†^ğºğ1\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ 1, i.e., the demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, the slightly scaled demand 11+4â¢Îµâ¢ğ114ğœ€ğ\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\ \mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G. By LemmaÂ 5.1, it suffices to prove a statement that is similar, but with the stronger hypothesis that ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths. And indeed, this is what we prove next by way of contradiction.

Suppose, for sake of a contradiction, there is a demand ğâ‰ 0ğ0\mathbf{d}\neq 0bold_d â‰  0 that can be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths, but 11+4â¢Îµâ¢ğ114ğœ€ğ\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d cannot be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G, i.e., Î»Gâ¢(ğ)<11+4â¢Îµsubscriptğœ†ğºğ114ğœ€\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})<\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_Îµ end_ARG. Let ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d by zeroing every coordinate dsâ¢tsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is smaller than 2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢t2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write this vector as ğâˆ’=ğâˆ’âˆ‘sâ¢tÎ±sâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tsuperscriptğğsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathbf{d}^{-}=\mathbf{d}-\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_d - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğsâ¢tsubscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the standard basis vector for pair (s,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¡(s,t)( italic_s , italic_t ), and Î±sâ¢t:=dsâ¢tassignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡\alpha_{st}:=d_{st}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if this value is smaller than 2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢t2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and otherwise Î±sâ¢t:=0assignsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡0\alpha_{st}:=0italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0. Round each nonzero coordinate of ğâˆ’superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT down to the next power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ, to obtain a demand vector ğUâ¢Bâ‰¥11+Îµâ¢ğâˆ’superscriptğğ‘ˆğµ11ğœ€superscriptğ\mathbf{d}^{UB}\geq\tfrac{1}{1+\varepsilon}\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Claim 6.10.

ğUâ¢B/(1+Îµ)2âˆˆğ’ŸUâ¢Bsuperscriptğğ‘ˆğµsuperscript1ğœ€2superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof of Claim 6.10.

Starting with the proof of conditionÂ (i) by way of contradiction, let us assume that demand ğUâ¢B/(1+Îµ)superscriptğğ‘ˆğµ1ğœ€\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths. The set of demands satisfiable in this manner (by 2222-hop flow paths in GğºGitalic_G) is convex and down-monotone, and by definition contains also the demands Fsâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tsubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T. Thus, a linear combination of vectors in the set, whose coefficients are non-negative and sum up to (1âˆ’Îµ)+âˆ‘s,tâˆˆTÎ±sâ¢tFsâ¢tâ‰¤(1âˆ’Îµ)+k22â‹…2â¢Î·=11ğœ€subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€â‹…superscriptğ‘˜222ğœ‚1(1-\varepsilon)+\sum_{s,t\in T}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\leq(1-\varepsilon)+\tfrac{k^{2}}{2}\cdot 2\eta=1( 1 - italic_Îµ ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) + divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‹… 2 italic_Î· = 1, must also be in the set. Taking the linear combination

we see that 11+4â¢Îµâ¢ğ114ğœ€ğ\frac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\,\mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_Îµ end_ARG bold_d can be satisfied in GğºGitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths, and clearly also without the restriction on the flow paths.
