We now prove conditionÂ (ii), which asserts that every nonzero coordinate dsâ¢tâ€²/(1+Îµ)2subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€2d^{\prime}_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is in the range [Î·â¢Fsâ¢t,Fsâ¢t]ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. One direction is immediate: if dsâ¢tâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡d^{\prime}_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-zero, then dsâ¢tâ€²â‰¥dsâ¢tâˆ’/(1+Îµ)â‰¥2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢t/(1+Îµ)â‰¥(1+Îµ)2â¢Î·â¢Fsâ¢tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡1ğœ€superscript1ğœ€2ğœ‚subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡d^{\prime}_{st}\geq d^{-}_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)\geq 2\eta F_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)\geq(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\eta F_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) â‰¥ 2 italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) â‰¥ ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the other direction, observe that Fsâ¢t>0subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡0F_{st}>0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 because otherwise GğºGitalic_G has no 2222-hop path of positive capacity between sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t, which implies the same in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, and we get dsâ¢tâ€²â‰¤dsâ¢t=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡0d^{\prime}_{st}\leq d_{st}=0italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. Define F~sâ¢tsubscript~ğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡\widetilde{F}_{st}over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be Fsâ¢tsubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡F_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rounded down to the next power of 1+Îµ1ğœ€1+\varepsilon1 + italic_Îµ, which means (1+Îµ)â¢F~sâ¢t>Fsâ¢t1ğœ€subscript~ğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡(1+\varepsilon)\widetilde{F}_{st}>F_{st}( 1 + italic_Îµ ) over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the corresponding demand F~sâ¢tâ¢ğsâ¢tâˆˆğ’ŸUâ¢Bsubscript~ğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ\widetilde{F}_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and using our assumption about all demands in ğ’ŸUâ¢Bsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, demand (1+Îµ)2â¢F~sâ¢tsuperscript1ğœ€2subscript~ğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\widetilde{F}_{st}( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be satisfied by flow along 2222-hop paths in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. Recalling that demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in that manner, we derive the other direction dsâ¢tâ€²â‰¤dsâ¢tâˆ’â‰¤dsâ¢t<(1+Îµ)2â¢F~sâ¢tâ‰¤(1+Îµ)2â¢Fsâ¢tsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€2subscript~ğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscript1ğœ€2subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡d^{\prime}_{st}\leq d^{-}_{st}\leq d_{st}<(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\widetilde{F}_{st}\leq(1+\varepsilon)^{2}F_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This completes the proof of requirement (ii), and of Claim 6.10. âˆ

We now finish the proof of Eqn.Â (6.10). Recall that we assumed the high probability event in LemmaÂ 6.6 occurred for every demand in ğ’ŸUâ¢Bsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ˆğµ{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using Claim 6.10 we know that ğUâ¢B/(1+Îµ)2superscriptğğ‘ˆğµsuperscript1ğœ€2\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_Îµ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the properties of LemmaÂ 6.6, which implies that the scaled-up demand ğUâ¢Bsuperscriptğğ‘ˆğµ\mathbf{d}^{UB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cannot be satisfied in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by flow along 2222-hop paths. Since ğUâ¢Bâ‰¤ğâˆ’â‰¤ğsuperscriptğğ‘ˆğµsuperscriptğğ\mathbf{d}^{UB}\leq\mathbf{d}^{-}\leq\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ bold_d, also demand ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d cannot be satisfied in this manner, but this contradicts the choice of ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d. This completes the proof of (6.10). âˆ

6.3 An Extension to More General Graphs

An extension of the techniques for quasi-bipartite graphs is to the following case: let GğºGitalic_G be a terminal network such that if we delete the terminal set Tğ‘‡Titalic_T then each component of Gâˆ–Tğºğ‘‡G\setminus Titalic_G âˆ– italic_T has at most wğ‘¤witalic_w nodes in it. (The case of quasi-bipartite graphs is precisely when w=1ğ‘¤1w=1italic_w = 1.) The sampling technique extends to this case; we now sketch the ideas for the extension.

Let the vertex sets of the components in Gâˆ–Tğºğ‘‡G\setminus Titalic_G âˆ– italic_T be V1,V2,â€¦,Vlsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘™V_{1},V_{2},\ldots,V_{l}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with each |Vi|â‰¤wsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘¤\lvert V_{i}\rvert\leq w| italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_w. (Again, assume Tğ‘‡Titalic_T forms an independent set.) For each s,tâˆˆTğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T, compute a max-flow that is terminal-free, i.e., it only uses flow-paths that go from sğ‘ sitalic_s to tğ‘¡titalic_t using vertices within a single Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and does not contain terminals as internal nodes. Let Fsâ¢t,isubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the value of this flow using Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Fsâ¢t=âˆ‘iFsâ¢t,isubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–F_{st}=\sum_{i}F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the value of the maximum sğ‘ sitalic_s-tğ‘¡titalic_t terminal-free flow itself. Observe that Fsâ¢t,isubscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also equals the value of the sğ‘ sitalic_s-tğ‘¡titalic_t min-cut within the graph Gâ¢[Viâˆª{s,t}]ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡G[V_{i}\cup\{s,t\}]italic_G [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª { italic_s , italic_t } ]. Define pi:=Mâ‹…maxâ¡{Fsâ¢t,iFsâ¢t:s,tâˆˆT}assignsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â‹…ğ‘€:subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‡p_{i}:=M\cdot\max\{{\frac{F_{st,i}}{F_{st}}:s,t\in T}\}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_M â‹… roman_max { divide start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG : italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_T }, and the sampling probability of component iğ‘–iitalic_i is then p~i:=minâ¡{pi,1}assignsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}:=\min\{p_{i},1\}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 }. Now we sample each component iğ‘–iitalic_i (i.e., keep subset Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) independently with probability p~isubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, in which case we scale the capacities of its incident edges by 1/p~i1subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–1/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}1 / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to get overall a graph G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

The analysis proceeds almost unchanged. The number of vertices in G^^ğº{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is now Oâ¢(k2â¢Mâ‹…w)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘€ğ‘¤O(k^{2}M\cdot w)italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M â‹… italic_w ) with high probability. The proof of the lower boundÂ (6.9) is unchanged, apart from replacing the use of 2222-hop paths by terminal-free paths. For the upper bound, we again write down the dual LP for terminal-free flows (analogous toÂ (LP4)), construct dual solutions {â„“esâ€²â¢tâ€²},{ysâ¢tsâ€²â¢tâ€²}subscriptsuperscriptâ„“superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡\{\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}\},\{y^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{st}\}{ roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , { italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } using the max-flow/min-cut duality (as in LemmaÂ 6.8), and argue that the contribution of each component iğ‘–iitalic_i to the LP value is bounded (as in ClaimÂ 6.9). The rest of the arguments in the upper bound proceed analogously to the quasi-bipartite case; details omitted.

7 Results Using Flow/Cut Gaps

Given the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network and demand matrix ğâ‰ 0ğ0\mathbf{d}\neq 0bold_d â‰  0, recall that Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) is the maximum multiple of ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d that can be sent through GğºGitalic_G. We can also define the sparsity of a cut (S,Vâˆ–S)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğ‘†(S,V\setminus S)( italic_S , italic_V âˆ– italic_S ) to be

Î¦Gâ¢(S;ğ):=âˆ‘eâˆˆâˆ‚Sceâˆ‘i,j:|{i,j}âˆ©S|=1diâ¢j,assignsubscriptÎ¦ğºğ‘†ğsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘’subscript:ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘†1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\Phi_{G}(S;\mathbf{d}):=\frac{\sum_{e\in\partial S}c_{e}}{\sum_{i,j:|\{i,j\}\cap S|=1}d_{ij}},roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ; bold_d ) := divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j : | { italic_i , italic_j } âˆ© italic_S | = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

and the sparsest cut as

Î¦Gâ¢(ğ):=minSâŠ†Vâ¡Î¦Gâ¢(S;ğ).assignsubscriptÎ¦ğºğsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘‰subscriptÎ¦ğºğ‘†ğ\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d}):=\min_{S\subseteq V}\Phi_{G}(S;\mathbf{d}).roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S âŠ† italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ; bold_d ) .

Define the flow-cut gap as

Î³â¢(G):=maxğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G)â¡Î¦Gâ¢(ğ)/Î»Gâ¢(ğ).assignğ›¾ğºsubscriptğğ’ŸğºsubscriptÎ¦ğºğsubscriptğœ†ğºğ\gamma(G):=\max_{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)}\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})/\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}).italic_Î³ ( italic_G ) := roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) .

It is easy to see that Î¦Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¥Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptÎ¦ğºğsubscriptğœ†ğºğ\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) for each demand vector ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d (and hence Î³â¢(G)â‰¥1ğ›¾ğº1\gamma(G)\geq 1italic_Î³ ( italic_G ) â‰¥ 1); a celebrated result ofÂ [LLR95, AR98] shows that for every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network GğºGitalic_G, the gap is Î³â¢(G)â‰¤Oâ¢(logâ¡k)ğ›¾ğºğ‘‚ğ‘˜\gamma(G)\leq O(\log k)italic_Î³ ( italic_G ) â‰¤ italic_O ( roman_log italic_k ). Many results are known about the flow-cut gap based on the structure of the graph GğºGitalic_G and that of the support of the demands in ğ’Ÿâ¢(G)ğ’Ÿğº{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ); in this section we use these results together with known results about cut sparsifiers, to derive new results about flow sparsifiers.

It will be convenient to generalize the notion of a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network. Given a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network G=(V,E,c)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸ğ‘G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) with its associated subset TâŠ†Vğ‘‡ğ‘‰T\subseteq Vitalic_T âŠ† italic_V of kğ‘˜kitalic_k terminals, define the demand-support to be another undirected graph H=(T,F)ğ»ğ‘‡ğ¹H=(T,F)italic_H = ( italic_T , italic_F ) with some subset of edges Fğ¹Fitalic_F between the terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. The demand polytope with respect to (G,H)ğºğ»(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is the set of all demand vectors ğ=(de)eâˆˆHğsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘’ğ»\mathbf{d}=(d_{e})_{e\in H}bold_d = ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which are supported on the edges in the demand-support Hğ»Hitalic_H, that are routable in GğºGitalic_G; i.e.,

ğ’Ÿâ¢(G,H):={ğâˆˆâ„+F:demandÂ ğÂ can be routed inÂ G}.assignğ’Ÿğºğ»conditional-setğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ¹demandÂ ğÂ can be routed inÂ G\displaystyle{\mathcal{D}}(G,H):=\{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{F}:\ \text{demand $\mathbf{d}$ can be routed in $G$}\}.caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ) := { bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : demand bold_d can be routed in italic_G } . (7.16)

This is a generalization ofÂ (2.5), where we defined Hğ»Hitalic_H to be the complete graph on the terminal setÂ Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Define the flow-cut gap with respect to the pair (G,H)ğºğ»(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) as

Î³â¢(G,H):=maxâ¡{Î¦Gâ¢(ğ)/Î»Gâ¢(ğ):ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G,H)âˆ–{0}}.assignğ›¾ğºğ»:subscriptÎ¦ğºğsubscriptğœ†ğºğğğ’Ÿğºğ»0\gamma(G,H):=\max\{{\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})/\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}):\ \mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G,H)\setminus\{0\}}\}.italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) := roman_max { roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) : bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ) âˆ– { 0 } } .

Analogously to a flow sparsifier, we can define cut-sparsifiers. Given a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network GğºGitalic_G with terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, a cut-sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G with quality Î²â‰¥1ğ›½1\beta\geq 1italic_Î² â‰¥ 1 is a graph Gâ€²=(Vâ€²,Eâ€²,câ€²)superscriptğºâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²superscriptğ¸â€²superscriptğ‘â€²G^{\prime}=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with TâŠ†Vâ€²ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‰â€²T\subseteq V^{\prime}italic_T âŠ† italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that for every partition (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, we have

mincutGâ¡(A,B)â‰¤mincutGâ€²â¡(A,B)â‰¤Î²â‹…mincutGâ¡(A,B).subscriptmincutğºğ´ğµsubscriptmincutsuperscriptğºâ€²ğ´ğµâ‹…ğ›½subscriptmincutğºğ´ğµ\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)\leq\beta\cdot\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B).roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) â‰¤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) â‰¤ italic_Î² â‹… roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) .

A cut-sparsifier Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is contraction-based if it is obtained from GğºGitalic_G by increasing the capacity of some edges and by identifying some vertices (from the perspective of cuts and flows, the latter is equivalent to adding infinite capacity edges between vertices).

Theorem 7.1.

Given a k-terminal network GğºGitalic_G with terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, let Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a quality Î²â‰¥1ğ›½1\beta\geq 1italic_Î² â‰¥ 1 cut-sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G. Then for every demand-support Hğ»Hitalic_H and all ğâˆˆâ„+Eâ¢(H)ğsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ¸ğ»\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{E(H)}bold_d âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E ( italic_H ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

1Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)â‰¤Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î²â‹…Î³â¢(G,H).1ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğsubscriptğœ†ğºğâ‹…ğ›½ğ›¾ğºğ»\displaystyle\frac{1}{\gamma(G^{\prime},H)}\leq\frac{\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})}{\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})}\leq\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H).divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG â‰¤ italic_Î² â‹… italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) . (7.17)

Therefore, the graph Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with edge capacities scaled up by Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)ğ›¾superscriptğºnormal-â€²ğ»\gamma(G^{\prime},H)italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) is a quality Î²â‹…Î³â¢(G,H)â‹…Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)normal-â‹…normal-â‹…ğ›½ğ›¾ğºğ»ğ›¾superscriptğºnormal-â€²ğ»\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)\cdot\gamma(G^{\prime},H)italic_Î² â‹… italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) â‹… italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) flow sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G for all demands supported on Hğ»Hitalic_H.

Moreover, if Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a contraction-based cut-sparsifier, then trivially Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğsubscriptğœ†superscriptğºnormal-â€²ğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), and hence Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT itself is a quality Î²â‹…Î³â¢(G,H)normal-â‹…ğ›½ğ›¾ğºğ»\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)italic_Î² â‹… italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) flow sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G for demands supported on Hğ»Hitalic_H.

Proof.

Consider a demand ğâˆˆğ’Ÿâ¢(G,H)ğğ’Ÿğºğ»\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G,H)bold_d âˆˆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ); the maximum multiple of it we can route is Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). For any partition (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of the terminal set Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, let dâ¢(A,B):=âˆ‘{i,j}:|{i,j}âˆ©A|=1diâ¢jassignğ‘‘ğ´ğµsubscript:ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d(A,B):=\sum_{\{i,j\}:|\{i,j\}\cap A|=1}d_{ij}italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_i , italic_j } : | { italic_i , italic_j } âˆ© italic_A | = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The flow across a cut cannot exceed that cutâ€™s capacity, hence Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‹…dâ¢(A,B)â‰¤mincutGâ¡(A,B)â‹…subscriptğœ†ğºğğ‘‘ğ´ğµsubscriptmincutğºğ´ğµ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\cdot d(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‹… italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) â‰¤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ). Since Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a cut sparsifier of GğºGitalic_G, we have mincutGâ¡(A,B)â‰¤mincutGâ€²â¡(A,B)subscriptmincutğºğ´ğµsubscriptmincutsuperscriptğºâ€²ğ´ğµ\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) â‰¤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ), and together we obtain

Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤mincutGâ¡(A,B)dâ¢(A,B).subscriptğœ†ğºğsubscriptmincutğºğ´ğµğ‘‘ğ´ğµ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\frac{\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)}{d(A,B)}.italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG .

Minimizing the right-hand side over all partitions (A,B)ğ´ğµ(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of the terminals, we have Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î¦Gâ€²â¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğsubscriptÎ¦superscriptğºâ€²ğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\Phi_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). The flow-cut gap for Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT implies that Î»Gâ¢(ğ)â‰¤Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)â‹…Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†ğºğâ‹…ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğ\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\gamma(G^{\prime},H)\cdot\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which shows the first inequality inÂ (7.17). For the second one, we just reverse the roles of GğºGitalic_G and Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the above argument, but now have to use that mincutGâ€²â¡(A,B)â‰¤Î²â‹…mincutGâ¡(A,B)subscriptmincutsuperscriptğºâ€²ğ´ğµâ‹…ğ›½subscriptmincutğºğ´ğµ\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)\leq\beta\cdot\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) â‰¤ italic_Î² â‹… roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) to get Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)Î²â‰¤mincutGâ¡(A,B)dâ¢(A,B)subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğğ›½subscriptmincutğºğ´ğµğ‘‘ğ´ğµ\frac{\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})}{\beta}\leq\frac{\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)}{d(A,B)}divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG, and hence eventually that Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)â‰¤Î²â‹…Î³â¢(G,H)â‹…Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğâ‹…â‹…ğ›½ğ›¾ğºğ»subscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\leq\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¤ italic_Î² â‹… italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) â‹… italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ).

For the second part of the theorem, observe that if Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is contraction-based, then it is a better flow network than GğºGitalic_G, which means Î»Gâ€²â¢(ğ)â‰¥Î»Gâ¢(ğ)subscriptğœ†superscriptğºâ€²ğsubscriptğœ†ğºğ\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) â‰¥ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). âˆ

This immediately allows us to infer the following results.

Corollary 7.2 (Single-Source Flow Sparsifiers).

For every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network GğºGitalic_G, there exists a graph Gâ€²superscriptğºnormal-â€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with 22ksuperscript2superscript2ğ‘˜2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vertices that preserves (exactly) all single-source and two-source flows.555A two-source flow means that there are two terminals tâ€²,tâ€²â€²âˆˆTsuperscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²â€²ğ‘‡t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}\in Titalic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_T such that every non-zero demand is incident to at least one of tâ€²,tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²â€²t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Single-source flows are defined analogously with a single terminal.

Proof.

Hagerup et al.Â [HKNR98] show that all graphs have (contraction-based) cut-sparsifiers with quality Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1italic_Î² = 1 and size 22ksuperscript2superscript2ğ‘˜2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see also [KRTV12] for a slight improvement for undirected graphs). Moreover, it is known that whenever Hğ»Hitalic_H has a vertex cover of size at most 2222, the flow-cut gap is exactly Î³â¢(G,H)=Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)=1ğ›¾ğºğ»ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»1\gamma(G,H)=\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1Â [Sch03, TheoremÂ 71.1c]. âˆ

Corollary 7.3 (Outerplanar Flow Sparsifiers).

If GğºGitalic_G is a planar graph where all terminals Tğ‘‡Titalic_T lie on the same face, then GğºGitalic_G has an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with Oâ¢(k2â¢22â¢k)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2superscript22ğ‘˜O(k^{2}2^{2k})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) vertices. In the special case where GğºGitalic_G is outerplanar, the size bound improves to Oâ¢(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ).

Proof.

Okamura and SeymourÂ [OS81] show that the flow-cut gap for planar graphs with all terminals on a single face is Î³â¢(G,H)=1ğ›¾ğºğ»1\gamma(G,H)=1italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = 1, and Krauthgamer and RikaÂ [KR13] show that every planar graph GğºGitalic_G has a contraction-based cut-sparsifier Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1italic_Î² = 1 and size Oâ¢(k2â¢22â¢k)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2superscript22ğ‘˜O(k^{2}2^{2k})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). And since the latter is contraction-based, also this Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is planar with all terminals on a single face, hence Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)=1ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»1\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1.

To improve the bound when GğºGitalic_G is outerplanar, we use a result of Chaudhuri et al.Â [CSWZ00, Theorem 5(ii)] that every outerplanar graph GğºGitalic_G has a cut-sparsifiers Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1italic_Î² = 1 and size Oâ¢(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ), and moreover, this also Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is outerplanar and thus Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)=1ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»1\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1. âˆ

Corollary 7.4 (4444-terminal Flow Sparsifiers).

For kâ‰¤4ğ‘˜4k\leq 4italic_k â‰¤ 4, every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network has an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with at most k+1ğ‘˜1k+1italic_k + 1 vertices.

Proof.

LomonosovÂ [Lom85] shows that the flow-cut gap for at most 4444 terminals is Î³â¢(G,H)=Î³â¢(Gâ€²,H)=1ğ›¾ğºğ»ğ›¾superscriptğºâ€²ğ»1\gamma(G,H)=\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_Î³ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = italic_Î³ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1, and Chaudhuri et al.Â [CSWZ00] show that all graphs with kâ‰¤5ğ‘˜5k\leq 5italic_k â‰¤ 5 terminals have cut-sparsifiers with quality Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1italic_Î² = 1 and at most k+1ğ‘˜1k+1italic_k + 1 vertices. (See also [KRTV12, Table 1].) âˆ

The above two results are direct corollaries, but we can use TheoremÂ 7.1 to get flow-sparsifiers with qualityÂ 1 from results on cut-sparsifiers, even when the flow-cut gap is more than 1111. E.g., for series-parallel graphs we know that the flow-cut gap is exactlyÂ 2Â [CJLV08, CSW13, LR10], but we give in the next section quality 1111 flow-sparsifiers by using cut-sparsifiers more directly.

7.1 Series-Parallel Graphs and Graphs of Bounded Treewidth

To begin, we give some definitions. An sğ‘ sitalic_s-tğ‘¡titalic_t series-parallel graph is defined recursively: it is eitherÂ (a)Â a single edge {s,t}ğ‘ ğ‘¡\{s,t\}{ italic_s , italic_t }, or (b)Â obtained by taking a parallel composition of two smaller sğ‘ sitalic_s-tğ‘¡titalic_t series-parallel graphs by identifying their sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t nodes, or (c)Â obtained by a series composition of an sğ‘ sitalic_s-xğ‘¥xitalic_x series-parallel graph with an xğ‘¥xitalic_x-tğ‘¡titalic_t series-parallel graph by identifying their xğ‘¥xitalic_x node. See FigureÂ 7.1. The vertices s,tğ‘ ğ‘¡s,titalic_s , italic_t are called the portals of GğºGitalic_G, and the rest of the vertices will be called the internal vertices.

Theorem 7.5 (Series-Parallel Graphs).

Every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal series-parallel network GğºGitalic_G admits an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with Oâ¢(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ) vertices.

Proof.

The way we build a series-parallel graph GğºGitalic_G gives us a decomposition tree ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T, where the leaves of ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T are edges in GğºGitalic_G, and each internal node prescribes either a series or a parallel combination of the graphs given by the two subtrees. We can label each node in ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T by the two portals. We will assume w.l.o.g.Â that ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T is binary.

Consider some decomposition tree ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T where the two portals for the root node are themselves terminals, and let the number of internal terminals in ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T be kğ‘˜kitalic_k (giving us a total of k+2ğ‘˜2k+2italic_k + 2 terminals, including the portals). We construct a sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G by working on the decomposition tree ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T recursively as follows, producing a sparsifier graph with at most Sâ¢(k)ğ‘†ğ‘˜S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ) vertices, for Sâ¢(k)ğ‘†ğ‘˜S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ) that will be determined later. Consider the two subtrees ğ’¯1,ğ’¯2subscriptğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯2\mathcal{T}_{1},\mathcal{T}_{2}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The easy case is when the number of internal terminals in ğ’¯1,ğ’¯2subscriptğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯2\mathcal{T}_{1},\mathcal{T}_{2}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we denote k1,k2subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2k_{1},k_{2}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are both strictly less than kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Let Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the graph defined by ğ’¯isubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–\mathcal{T}_{i}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In case G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are composed in parallel, recursively construct for them sparsifiers G1â€²,G2â€²superscriptsubscriptğº1â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2â€²G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and compose these two sparsifiers in parallel to get Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the Composition LemmaÂ 5.2 implies this is a sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G. In case they are in series, the middle vertex may not be a terminal: so add it as a new terminal, recurse on G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and again compose G1â€²,G2â€²subscriptsuperscriptğºâ€²1subscriptsuperscriptğºâ€²2G^{\prime}_{1},G^{\prime}_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In either case, the number of internal vertices in the new graph is Sâ¢(k)â‰¤Sâ¢(k1)+Sâ¢(k2)+1ğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜21S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+1italic_S ( italic_k ) â‰¤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + 1, where we account for adding the middle vertex as a terminal.

Now suppose all the kğ‘˜kitalic_k internal terminals of the root of ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T are also internal terminals of ğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯1\mathcal{T}_{1}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, find the node in ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T furthest from the root such that the subtree ğ’¯â€²superscriptğ’¯â€²\mathcal{T}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rooted at this node still has kğ‘˜kitalic_k internal terminals, but neither of its child subtrees ğ’¯1â€²,ğ’¯2â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’¯1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’¯2â€²\mathcal{T}_{1}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{2}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains all the kğ‘˜kitalic_k internal terminals.666The easy case above is in fact a special case of this, where ğ’¯â€²=ğ’¯superscriptğ’¯â€²ğ’¯\mathcal{T}^{\prime}=\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_T. There must be such a node, because the leaves of ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T contain no internal terminals. Say the portals of ğ’¯â€²superscriptğ’¯â€²\mathcal{T}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are sâ€²,tâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. And say the graphs given by ğ’¯â€²,ğ’¯1â€²,ğ’¯2â€²superscriptğ’¯â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’¯1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ’¯2â€²\mathcal{T}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{1}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{2}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Gâ€²,G1â€²,G2â€²superscriptğºâ€²superscriptsubscriptğº1â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2â€²G^{\prime},G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The picture looks like one of the cases in FigureÂ 7.2.

Add the two portals sâ€²,tâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and if it was a series combination then also the middle vertex xğ‘¥xitalic_x between G1â€²,G2â€²superscriptsubscriptğº1â€²superscriptsubscriptğº2â€²G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as new terminals. Observe that GğºGitalic_G is obtained by composing Gâˆ–Gâ€²ğºsuperscriptğºâ€²G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G âˆ– italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (at the new terminals sâ€²,tâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), hence we can apply the Composition Lemma to the sparsifiers for Gâˆ–Gâ€²ğºsuperscriptğºâ€²G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G âˆ– italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and for Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We can use CorollaryÂ 7.4 to find a flow sparsifier for Gâˆ–Gâ€²ğºsuperscriptğºâ€²G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G âˆ– italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: it has only 4444 terminals s,t,sâ€²,tâ€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²s,t,s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s , italic_t , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Overall, we obtain a flow sparsifier for GğºGitalic_G with at most Sâ¢(k)â‰¤Sâ¢(k1)+Sâ¢(k2)+(c4âˆ’4)+3ğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘443S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+(c_{4}-4)+3italic_S ( italic_k ) â‰¤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 4 ) + 3 internal vertices, where the number of new vertices generated by CorollaryÂ 7.4 is at most c4âˆ’4subscriptğ‘44c_{4}-4italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 4, and we added in at most 3333 new terminals (namely sâ€²,tâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and possibly xğ‘¥xitalic_x).

In either case, we arrive at the recurrence Sâ¢(k)â‰¤Sâ¢(k1)+Sâ¢(k2)+c4ğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘4S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+c_{4}italic_S ( italic_k ) â‰¤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where k1+k2â‰¤ksubscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘˜k_{1}+k_{2}\leq kitalic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_k and k1,k2â‰¥1subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜21k_{1},k_{2}\geq 1italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 1. The base case is when there are at most 2222 internal terminals, in which case we can use CorollaryÂ 7.4 again to get Sâ¢(1),Sâ¢(2)â‰¤c4ğ‘†1ğ‘†2subscriptğ‘4S(1),S(2)\leq c_{4}italic_S ( 1 ) , italic_S ( 2 ) â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The recurrence solves to Sâ¢(k)â‰¤(2â¢kâˆ’1)â‹…c4ğ‘†ğ‘˜â‹…2ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘4S(k)\leq(2k-1)\cdot c_{4}italic_S ( italic_k ) â‰¤ ( 2 italic_k - 1 ) â‹… italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Adding the two portal terminals of ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T still remains Oâ¢(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ), and proves the theorem. âˆ

7.2 Extension to Treewidth-wğ‘¤witalic_w Graphs

The general theorem about bounded treewidth graphs follows a similar argument but with looser bounds. The only fact about a treewidth-wğ‘¤witalic_w graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) we use is the following.

Theorem 7.6 ([Ree92]).

If a graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) has treewidth wğ‘¤witalic_w, then for every subset TâŠ†Vğ‘‡ğ‘‰T\subseteq Vitalic_T âŠ† italic_V, there exists a subset XâŠ†Vğ‘‹ğ‘‰X\subseteq Vitalic_X âŠ† italic_V of wğ‘¤witalic_w vertices such that each component of Gâˆ’Xğºğ‘‹G-Xitalic_G - italic_X contains at most 23â¢|Tâˆ–X|23ğ‘‡ğ‘‹\frac{2}{3}|T\setminus X|divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG | italic_T âˆ– italic_X | vertices of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T.

Theorem 7.7.

Suppose every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network admits a flow sparsifier of quality qâ¢(k)ğ‘ğ‘˜q(k)italic_q ( italic_k ) and size Sâ¢(k)ğ‘†ğ‘˜S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ). Then every kğ‘˜kitalic_k-terminal network GğºGitalic_G with treewidth wğ‘¤witalic_w has a qâ¢(6â¢w)ğ‘6ğ‘¤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w )-quality flow sparsifier with at most k4â‹…Sâ¢(6â¢w)normal-â‹…superscriptğ‘˜4ğ‘†6ğ‘¤k^{4}\cdot S(6w)italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_S ( 6 italic_w ) vertices.

Proof.

The proof is by induction. Consider a graph GğºGitalic_G: if it has at most 6â¢w6ğ‘¤6w6 italic_w terminals, we just build a qâ¢(6â¢w)ğ‘6ğ‘¤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w )-quality vertex sparsifier of size Sâ¢(6â¢w)ğ‘†6ğ‘¤S(6w)italic_S ( 6 italic_w ).

Else, let Tğ‘‡Titalic_T be the set of terminals in GğºGitalic_G, and use TheoremÂ 7.6 to find a set Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X such that each component of Gâˆ’Xğºğ‘‹G-Xitalic_G - italic_X contains at most 23â¢|Tâˆ–X|23ğ‘‡ğ‘‹\frac{2}{3}|T\setminus X|divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG | italic_T âˆ– italic_X | terminals. Suppose the components have vertex sets V1,V2,â€¦,Vlsubscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘™V_{1},V_{2},\ldots,V_{l}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; let Gi:=Gâ¢[ViâˆªX]assignsubscriptğºğ‘–ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘‹G_{i}:=G[V_{i}\cup X]italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_G [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª italic_X ]. Recurse on each Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with terminal set (Tâˆ©Vi)âˆªXğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ‘‹(T\cap V_{i})\cup X( italic_T âˆ© italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆª italic_X to find a flow sparsifier Giâ€²superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–â€²G_{i}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of quality qâ¢(6â¢w)ğ‘6ğ‘¤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w ). Now use the Composition lemma to merge these sparsifiers Giâ€²superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–â€²G_{i}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT together and give the sparsifier Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the same quality. If the number of terminals in GğºGitalic_G was kGsubscriptğ‘˜ğºk_{G}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the number of terminals in each Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is smaller by at least 13â¢kGâˆ’w=kG/613subscriptğ‘˜ğºğ‘¤subscriptğ‘˜ğº6\frac{1}{3}k_{G}-w=k_{G}/6divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w = italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 6, and hence kGiâ‰¤5/6â¢kGsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğºğ‘–56subscriptğ‘˜ğºk_{G_{i}}\leq 5/6\,k_{G}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 5 / 6 italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence the depth of the recursion is at most h:=log6/5â¡(k/w)â‰¤log6/5â¡kassignâ„subscript65ğ‘˜ğ‘¤subscript65ğ‘˜h:=\log_{6/5}(k/w)\leq\log_{6/5}kitalic_h := roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 / 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k / italic_w ) â‰¤ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 / 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k, and the number of leaves is at most 2hsuperscript2â„2^{h}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using, e.g., results from Englert et al.Â [EGK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT10] we can achieve qâ¢(k)=Oâ¢(logâ¡klogâ¡logâ¡k)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘˜q(k)=O\big{(}\frac{\log k}{\log\log k}\big{)}italic_q ( italic_k ) = italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) and Sâ¢(k)=kğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘˜S(k)=kitalic_S ( italic_k ) = italic_k, which gives the results stated in SectionÂ 1.
